Span: [157041, 157059]
Span: [157282, 157285]
Span: [157391, 157393]

Span: [157403, 157406]

Span: [157439, 157441]
Span: [157582, 157585]
Span: [157693, 157695]
Span: [157718, 157721]
Span: [157834, 157836]
Span: [157853, 157856]
Text: Under these conditions , carbon is converted to carbon dioxide and again quantified in the coulometer
Text: This result is referred to as 'elemental carbon ' ( EC ) and represents the carbon particles in the diesel exhaust
Text: The OC and EC results can be added to provide a 'total carbon ' ( TC ) figure
Text: Field blank filters were analysed with each batch of samples and the sample results corrected appropriately
Text: Pyrolytic formation of EC from diesel exhaust particulate during the OC measurement stage has not been detected using the conditions of analysis reported here .
Text: The measurement of aldehydes ( acrolein , formaldehyde and acetaldehyde ) was attempted at some background locations using glass fibre filters treated with 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine ( DNPH ) sampling at 200 ml min~1
Text: However , it became apparent that not only is DNPH unsuitable for the measurement of acrolein because of the formation of multiple reaction products but the DNPH itself was affected at some locations by other components of diesel exhaust
Text: Consequently , this measurement was abandoned .
Text: Personal samples were collected in the breathing zones of workers potentially exposed to diesel exhaust during their working shift
Text: Static samples were placed in locations where personnel worked and occasionally in those areas where it was impractical to collect personal samples
Text: Wherever possible , sampling times were at least 6 h duration to ensure collection of sufficient carbon for analysis but some processes inevitably resulted in shorter sampling periods
Text: All results reported here are representative of 8 h time weighted exposures .
Text: In summary , each set of personal and background samples provided results on : respirable particulate , elemental carbon , organic carbon , total carbon , carbon dioxide , carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides .
Text: RESULTS
Text: A total of 691 respirable dust samples were collected
Text: One personal sample was omitted from analysis because of pump failure
Text: A further 5 personals and 29 background samples were declared invalid because of filter damage ( producing negative weight gains ) leaving a total of 656 respirable dust samples split between 215 personals and 441 background samples
Text: Close examination of the respirable dust results required the elimination of a further 65 samples ( 26 personal , 39 background ) because the sum of the elemental carbon and organic carbon analyses exceeded the respirable particulate on the filter
Text: This probably reflects the difficulties in handling quartz filters which are prone to shed fibres during handling
Text: All respirable dust masses in the survey were corrected by weighing blank filters in the usual way
Text: A total of 189 personal and 402 background respirable dust results were accepted as valid .
Text: Estimates of the limit of detection for weighing quartz filters ( based on three times the standard deviation of the blanks ) ranged during the survey from about 21 up to 120 ug for a random selection of 10 batches of samples
Text: The median value of 45 ug was adopted as representative of the overall limit of detection
Text: The median air volume sampled was 714 litres
Text: Combining this with the limit of detection for weighing gives 63 ng m-3 as the detection limit for airborne concentration of respirable dust
Text: Any values reported below this concentration were assigned a value equal to half the detection limit as is the usual convention
Text: The estimated detection limit for both EC and OC was 10 ug
Text: Using the median volume of air given above , this equates to an airborne detection limit of 1 4 u g m-3 for both EC and OC
Text: Values reported below this concentration were allocated a value of half the detection limit
Text: Total carbon is simply the sum of elemental and organic carbon .
Text: Of the respirable dust samples collected , 220 personals and 244 backgrounds were analysed for EC and OC ( these included some samples which produced invalid respirable dust results but which were nevertheless analysed for carbon content )
Text: During analysis , nine EC and one OC analysis failed
Text: Consequently , results are reported for 217 personal and 237 background EC analyses and 220 personal and 243 background OC analyses .
Text: Respirable dust
Text: Table 2 shows that the geometric mean ( GM ) for 189 personal exposures to respirable dust was 208 ug m-3
Text: Ambulance depots recorded the lowest exposures ( 118ugm~3 ) but exposures where forklift trucks were in use were nearly twice those of the other groups ( 369 ug m~3 )
Text: The fork-lift truck category also recorded the maximum respirable dust value
Text: Except for the ambulance category , the exposures for background samples are all lower than the corresponding personal samples
Text: The geometric standard deviations ( GSD ) for the personal samples are around two for each workgroup except for the ro-ro ferries with a value of 2.7 which perhaps reflects the non-repetitive nature of the work
Text: Two background samples at site 34 ( group 7 ) produced respirable masses of about 8 mg m~3 which are clearly unusually high .
Text: Elemental carbon
Text: The GM concentration for 217 personal exposures to elemental carbon was 25 ug m^3 ( Table 3 )
Text: Fork-lift trucks provided the highest GM exposure ( 66 ug m~3 ) , ro-ro ferries were ranked second ( 37 ug m~3 ) and the lowest exposures were at vehicle testing stations ( l l u g m ~ 3 )
Text: Background exposures to elemental carbon within the work categories were very similar to the personal exposures with an overall background exposure of 24 ug m~3
Text: Within the groups , fork-lift trucks were an exception since the geometric mean background was about 30 % higher than the corresponding personal exposure
Text: Ro-ro ferries were the only category where personal exposures exceeded background exposures to any degree
Text: The close equivalence of personal and background exposures suggests that the elemental carbon is relatively homogeneously dispersed in the measured atmospheres
Text: This might indicate that those people in the same work area but not directly involved in the process generating diesel exhaust might also be significantly exposed .
Text: ii
Text: Bus drivers
Text: It was not always possible to obtain personal exposure measurements during this study because of objections raised by either management or union personnel
Text: This was the case with the bus driver sampling
Text: Two members of the project team acted as surrogates for the bus drivers and rode the Metropolitan Transit buses for 6–8 h wearing personal samplers
Text: It was assumed that their exposures would be similar to those of the bus drivers as they sat as close to the bus driver as possible
Text: The surrogates got off the bus at the end of each route and waited for the next bus to take them back to their point of origin
Text: The same bus typically would not run the same route all day long
Text: In fact , each bus route would have several bus drivers in different buses throughout the day
Text: The amount of time spent on the buses was recorded daily
Text: Table 1 shows the average sampling time duration and standard deviation for each bus route
Text: Four bus routes ( 16 , 27 , 75 and 80 ) were selected , prior to sampling , based on their traffic patterns .
Text: The personal air monitoring of the bus routes comprised 39 air samples for EC divided , roughly equally , among four different bus routes in the Minneapolis-St
Text: Paul metropolitan area ( shown in Table 1 )
Text: Route 16 traveled between downtown Minneapolis to downtown St
Text: Paul where the bulk of the traffic was a mixture of spark ignition commuter automobiles with some diesel truck traffic
Text: Route 27 traveled between downtown Minneapolis to suburban Anoka approximately 20 miles away
Text: Traffic comprised spark ignition autos and diesel trucks that followed this route to various industrial sites
Text: Route 75 was also a suburban corridor to downtown Minneapolis but with somewhat lighter diesel truck traffic
Text: Route 80 went from downtown Minneapolis to the Mall of America , Bloomington , MN and comprised mostly of freeway traffic along an interstate highway
Text: The Mall has a semi-enclosed bus terminal with constant bus traffic
Text: Much of this traffic consisted of buses that were idling while unloading , loading , and waiting for passengers .
Text: A total of 39 personal EC samples were collected on the four routes as shown in Table 1
Text: Only a single set of portable , battery powered , PAS and DC instruments was available for this study
Text: When used on the buses , the instruments were placed in the laps of the surrogate bus drivers with a common sampling tube extending into the breathing zone next to the EC sampler
Text: The instruments stored a running 10 s average of the surface area or PAH concentration in memory
Text: Data were downloaded daily to a computer
Text: The PAS was used on eight bus sampling days and the DC was used on six bus sampling days
Text: On these days , project personnel maintained a log of heavy and light-duty traffic encountered on the bus routes
Text: Traffic counts were recorded every minute .
Text: iv
Text: Parking ramp attendants .
Text: Parking ramp attendants at two ramps ( the 4th Street ramp and the Washington Avenue ramp on the University of Minnesota campus ) were monitored
Text: They were exposed to a mixed aerosol , although the bulk of the parking ramp traffic was automobiles
Text: The attendants were housed in booths with positive pressure ventilation and windows , but the intake vents for both ramps were located near potential sources of vehicle exhaust aerosol so workers may have been exposed to vehicular aerosol generated from sources that were not in the immediate vicinity of the parking ramp booth
Text: The Washington Avenue ramp is one of the busiest campus parking facilities with constant in and out traffic
Text: The 4th street ramp has periods with heavy commuter traffic in the morning and afternoon .
Text: The EC samplers were placed near the breathing zone of the parking ramp attendants and close to the open window
Text: There were several parking ramp attendants that worked in the booth throughout the day , to ensure that sufficient mass was collected for the chemical analysis of EC , it was decided to keep the cyclone near the breathing zone for several attendants rather than limit the sampling to one specific individual during a day
Text: Typically , sampling began in the morning and ended in the late evening ( average sampling times and standard deviations are shown in Table 1 )
Text: In addition to EC samples , we also used the portable PAS and DC instruments as shown in Table 1
Text: At the Washington Avenue ramp the SMPS and UCPC were also used
Text: Twelve of the 23 EC samples were taken concurrently with the real-time measurements .
Text: v
Text: Bus garage mechanics
Text: The garage phase of this study was selected to provide an environment thought to be dominated by diesel aerosol
Text: Although exposure was primarily from diesel aerosol , cigarette smoke and other submicron aerosol such as welding fume may also have been present
Text: The selected locations were the Camden garage in Minneapolis and the Cedar Avenue garage in Richfield , MN
Text: The primary activity at both garages was diesel engine maintenance .
Text: Instrumentation included EC samplers , the UCPC , and the portable PAS and DC samplers as shown in Table 1
Text: Nineteen EC samples were taken at the Camden garage at three different locations
Text: Seven samples were collected simultaneously with the real-time instruments located in the main garage area where most of the engines were maintained
Text: The other nine were split between a maintenance bay that was separated from the main garage area and used by maintenance workers and a loft location that was one story above the instruments and used by clerical workers
Text: The Cedar Avenue garage was relatively new , and the same instrumentation was used
Text: Fifteen EC samples were obtained at the garage , and six of these samples were collected simultaneously with the real-time instruments .
Text: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Text: This section is divided into three parts , each part describing the exposure assessment results based on a different exposure metric-mass concentration , surface area concentration , and number concentration
Text: Table 2 presents summary statistics for the three exposure groups using the different exposure metrics
Text: We used Analysis of Variance ( ANOVA ) for statistical comparisons using the S-Plus software package ( Insightful Corporation , 2002 )
Text: A
Text: Mass concentration measurements
Text: Fig
Text: 1 shows box plots of EC concentrations for all three occupational categories—bus drivers , parking ramp booth attendants , and garage mechanics
Text: The specific locations at which measurements were made , i.e. , four bus routes , two parking ramps , and two garages with three locations each further divide these categories
Text: The line inside each of the boxes is the median , the ends of the boxes are the 25th and 75th percentiles , and the ends of the lines are the 10th and the 90th percentiles of the measurements
Text: The solid circles are the 5th and the 95th percentiles
Text: Each measurement is the average EC concentration over a work shift ( typically 6–7 hours )
Text: A number of measurements in the ramps and buses were close to or below the limit of detection ~1 mg m 3 )
Text: The three groups had statistically significant differences in exposures to EC as shown in Table 2 ( p < 0.001 )
Text: The least squares mean exposures and corresponding standard errors were 3.87 +- 0.60 mg m3 for garage mechanics , 1.98 +- 0.21 mg m 3 for bus drivers , and 1.10 +- 0.11 mg m 3 for ramp attendants
Text: The highest levels of EC were seen in the maintenance garages that were dominated by diesel exhaust and the lowest levels were observed in the parking ramp booths that were dominated by spark ignition ( gasoline ) exhaust aerosol
Text: The four bus routes had a hybrid of diesel/spark ignition exposure , and had intermediate levels of EC
Text: The EC levels ranged ( 5th to 95th percentiles ) from the method detection limit ( MDL = 1 mg m3 ) to 5.6 mg m for the four bus routes , MDL to 2.30 mg m 3 in the ramps , and MDL to 17.7 mg m 3 in the garages .
Text: Very low EC concentrations in the parking ramp booths are consistent with the facts that there was very little diesel traffic , that the booths were under positive pressure and the measurements were made inside the booth near the breathing zone of the attendants .
Text: The Camden garage had statistically significant higher concentrations than the Cedar Avenue garage
Text: The mean and standard errors of EC levels were 3.4 0.5 mg m 3 for Camden , and 1.1 0.5 mg m 3 for Cedar Avenue garage
Text: Camden is an older garage with less ventilation
Text: The Cedar Avenue garage is relatively new with better ventilation , which is reflected in the lower EC concentrations .
Text: The results from the bus garages are consistent with a previous study conducted by NIOSH of trucking industry workers.52 In that study the geometric mean EC exposure was 3.8 mg m 3 for highway truck drivers , 4.0 mg m 3 for local truck drivers , 12.1 mg m 3 for bus mechanics , and 27.2 mg m 3 for dockworkers using diesel-powered forklift trucks
Text: In the same study , background levels measured in a residential area and near the highway ranged from 1–3 mg m 3 , similar to the levels we measured in the buses and parking ramps .
Text: B
Text: Surface area concentration measurements
Text: As mentioned earlier , the diffusion charger ( DC ) measures the total surface area of the particles irrespective of their chemistry , while the photoelectric aerosol sensor ( PAS ) measures the surface adsorbed PAHs—a surrogate for the surface area of diesel exhaust aerosol specifically .
Text: Fig
Text: 2 shows a box plot comparison of the 10-second average DC measurements in buses , parking ramps , and bus garages
Text: Table 2 shows that the arithmetic mean 10-second average surface area concentrations in parking ramps are significantly greater than those in bus garages , which in turn are significantly greater than those in buses
Text: However , the much larger exposures in ramp attendants are due to a few large exposure occasions
Text: This can be seen by comparing the GSDs of the exposure distributions for the three groups
Text: The large standard deviation for ramp attendants results from a few very high exposure conditions
Text: Table 2 also shows that the work shift average surface area concentrations ( arithmetic as well as geometric means ) for the three occupational groups are not much different from the 10-second averages
Text: However , the three groups are not significantly different for work shift average surface area concentrations
Text: As expected , the range of values for work shift average values is narrower than for 10-second averages .
Text: Applied Occupational and Environmental Hygiene
Text: Abstract :
Text: The purpose of this study was to characterize respirable dust , crystalline silica , diesel , and noise exposures to construction workers on a large highway construction project in Boston , Massachusetts
Text: The study primarily focused on operating engineers and laborers , and to a lesser extent on ironworkers and carpenters during the tunnel finish and cut and cover stages
Text: Full and partial shift noise dosimeter measurements were collected
Text: Eighty percent of the 40 noise measurements were at or above 85 dBA , with the operating engineers averaging 91 dBA .
Text: Sample collection for respirable dust , crystalline silica , and diesel particulates measured as elemental carbon was done using cyclones and personal cascade impactors
Text: Exposure to respirable dust ranged from 0.06 to 21.77 mg/m3 for the 77 workers sampled , with the laborers having the highest mean concentration of 2.85 mg/m3 .
Text: The respirable quartz measurements for the 32 samples colected ranged from the detection limit of 0.008 mg/m3 to 1.64 mg/m3 , with the highest mean concentration of 0.31 mg/m3 attributed to the laborers
Text: The use of drills , when compared to other machine types , produced the highest exposures to respirable quartz
Text: The levels for elemental carbon ranged from 4 to 178 g/m3 ( mean of 41 g/m3 ) inside enclosed work spaces , compared with 0.5 to 53 g/m3 ( mean of 10 g/m3 ) for samples collected in unenclosed work sites .
Text: Statistical modeling of the factors influencing the elemental carbon exposures showed that machine type , worker distance from the diesel source , the number of other diesel sources in the work area , and site enclosure were all significant exposure determinants
Text: The results indicate that high exposures to noise , respirable dust , and crystalline silica are common in the highway construction industry .
Text: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Text: Noise
Text: Thirty-six personal noise dosimetry measurements were collected among different individual workers using Quest Q-100 noise dosimeters ( Quest Electronics , Oconomowac , Wisconsin ) , with an 80 dBA threshold level
Text: Half of the samples were collected for approximately one hour , while the remaining noise measurements were for six-hour intervals
Text: Extrapolation to an 8-hour time-weighted average ( TWA ) was performed assuming that the noise level measured during the sample period would be consistent throughout the entire work shift .
Text: This assumption was considered valid because workers often performed similar tasks throughout an entire workday , a trend observed by the industrial hygienists on site
Text: The noise measurements represented several trades in a variety of tasks , including laborers performing drilling and chipping activities , as well as operating engineers running heavy equipment
Text: Area samples were collected to evaluate the general noise levels for the large number of tile setters and other trades people completing work within enclosed areas
Text: Each noise dosimeter was calibrated before and after sampling using a Quest QC-10 calibrator
Text: The daily integrated noise measurements were downloaded to a printer , producing a time history of noise exposure
Text: Although specific tasks and areas were chosen for measurement , isolation of contributing noise sources was not possible .
Text: A questionnaire was administered to a subset of the workers ( n = 26 ) wearing the noise dosimetry equipment to determine their attitudes concerning hearing protection devices ( HPDs ) and hearing loss
Text: Various unions were represented in this sample including operating engineers , laborers , pile drivers , ironworkers , carpenters , and tunnel workers
Text: Questions referred to the workers ' perception and usage of HPDs
Text: The following were questions of particular interest : How often do you wear hearing protection ? Do you believe that if you continue to work in this environment you will develop some form of hearing loss ? Do you believe that wearing a hearing protection device will reduce your long-term hearing loss ? Answers were multiple choice , representing a range of responses .
Text: Particle Collection
Text: Personal and area particulate samples were collected during field visits to the ITT , cut and cover , and outdoor areas
Text: A number of variables with the potential to modify exposures were collected concurrently with the particulate samples
Text: These variables were recorded through the observations of the on-site personnel collecting the samples
Text: A small percentage of the personal samples were repeat samples collected on different days for the same individual .
Text: Respirable dust samples were collected on either tared 5 mm PVC filters ( MSA , Pittsburgh , Pennsylvania ) or tared quartz filters ( Pallflex Products Co. , Putnam , Connecticut ) and housed in either two- or three-piece plastic cassettes .
Text: Sample collection was performed using either a BGI-4 Higgins & Dewell ( Waltham , Massachusetts ) , an MSA 10 mm nylon Dorr-Oliver ( Pittsburgh , Pennsylvania ) , or an SKC Aluminum ( Eighty Four , Pennsylvania ) personal cyclone at a sampling flow rate of 2.2 , 1.7 , or 1.9 liters per minute ( lpm ) , respectively
Text: Particle size selective samples were collected using the Sierra 290 Series personal cascade impactor ( Graseby Anderson , Inc. , Smyrna , Georgia )
Text: The upper stages were collected on mylar substrate sprayed with 316 Silicone Release Spray ( Dow Corning Corporation , Midland , Michigan ) to prevent particle bounce .
Text: The final stage media was either a 5 mm PVC filter or a quartz filter
Text: The impactor was set up with either the 5A stage , or the 3 and 5A stages , and the backup filter in place
Text: At a flow rate of 2 lpm , the5A stage has a cutpoint of9.8lm and the 3stage has a cutpoint of 3.5 l m , each with a geometric standard deviation ( GSD ) of 1.21
Text: Because the backup filter of the impactor primarily collects particles less than 3.5 l m , it is an under- estimate of the respirable size selective mass fraction defined by ACGIH
Text: Nevertheless , when the data were examined by union or machine type , an analysis of variance procedure found no significant difference in the logarithm of the dust concentration of the impactor backup filter and the cyclone ( Tables II and III ) .
Text: Therefore , for the purposes of this article , the particulate samples collected with the cyclone and the impactor backup filter are combined to provide an estimate of the respirable particulate exposures of construction workers .
Text: To evaluate whether diesel exhaust fume was agglomerating or adsorbing onto larger construction particulate , six inhalable particulate samplers were paired with respirable ( cyclone ) samplers to collect side-by-side diesel exhaust samples
Text: The inhalable sampler was an adaptation of the UK 7 hole sampler with the particulate collected on a 37 mm quartz filter at a sampling flow rate of 2 lpm .
Text: Air flow pumps for all samples were calibrated indoors prior to and following site visits using a precision rotometer
Text: When sampling was conducted at a substantially different temperature than that at the time of calibration , an adjustment to the measured air volume was made to obtain the actual air volume sampled .
Text: Sample Analysis
Text: Gravimetric analysis of the respirable , inhalable , and particle size selective samples was initially conducted at the Wisconsin Occupational Health Laboratory ( WOHL ) in Madison , Wisconsin , and , subsequently , at the University of Massachusetts Lowell Industrial Hygiene Laboratory using NIOSH Method 0600 .
Text: Following gravimetric measurement , the 5 mm PVC filter samples were analyzed for crystalline silica
Text: Determination of the crystalline silica content was conducted primarily at the WOHL using x-ray diffraction ( NIOSH method 7500 ) with only a few samples analyzed by Liberty Mutual Analytical Laboratory ( Hopkinton , Massachusetts ) using infrared absorption spectroscopy ( NIOSH Method 7602 )
Text: Elemental carbon analysis was used as a marker of diesel exhaust to avoid contamination by cigarette smoke or other combustion or construction sources
Text: A similar approach was used in a study of diesel exhaust exposures in the trucking industry .
Text: The samples collected on quartz filters were analyzed for elemental and organic carbon by Sunset Laboratory ( Forest Grove , Oregon ) utilizing a thermal-optical technique
Text: The filters were refrigerated after sampling and shipped to the laboratory on ice .
Text: The thermal-optical analytical technique involves a two- step procedure
Text: The samples are put into an oxygen-free helium atmosphere and heated in four increasing temperature steps to remove all organic carbon from the filters .
Text: A laser is used to monitor the accidental pyrolytic conversion of organic carbon to elemental carbon
Text: The organic compounds are oxidized to carbon dioxide and detected by a flame ionization detector ( FID )
Text: After cooling , a two percent oxygen/helium mixture is switched into the sample oven and the oven is stepped up to 850±C for analysis of elemental carbon , again by FID .
Text: Most of the samples were well above the limit of detection of 0.2 l g/m3 for elemental carbon .
Text: Statistical Analysis
Text: The sampling results and field data variables were entered into a FOXPro database ( Microsoft Corporation , Redmond , Washington ) and then downloaded into SAS software for the PC ( Statistical Analysis System , Cary , North Carolina ) .
Text: Contaminant analyses reported by the laboratory as less than the detection limit were included in the statistical analyses by assigning the sample the value of the detection limit divided by the square root of two .
Text: There were two elemental carbon and four silica samples at the limit of detection
Text: A total of 68 elemental carbon , 102 respirable dust , 51 quartz , and 47 percent silica samples were analyzed with the SAS software .
Text: Examination of the data through log and normal probability plots and the use of the Shapiro-Wilk 's statistic showed that the samples fit a lognormal distribution better than a normal distribution
Text: Thus , all statistical analysis includes the geometric mean and standard deviation calculated from the logarithmically transformed mass concentration values .
Text: A statistical model was developed to estimate the effect of various exposure modifiers on the natural logarithm of the elemental carbon levels
Text: The modeling effort began with a single factor analysis of variance ( ANOVA ) of the nine variables suspected of influencing the personal diesel exposure level : the machine type ( n = 4 ) , the number of sides enclosed on the machine ( 0 , 3 , or 4 ) , the presence/absence of an exhaust scrubber , the amount of time the machine was actually performing work ( 0 to 1.5 hours , 2 to 3.5 hours , or 4 to 5.75 hours )
Text: the degree of enclosure of the site ( closed versus open ) , the distance from the source of the exhaust to the sampling media ( < = 10 feet , 10 to 20 feet , or > 20 feet ) , the number of other diesel sources in the area ( < = 1 or > 1 ) , the union to which the worker belonged , and whether or not the worker smoked cigarettes during that workday .
Text: Personal Exposures to Inorganic and Organic Dust in Manual Harvest of California Citrus and Table Grapes
Text: ABSTRACT
Text: The aim of this study was to determine characteristics of personal exposure to inorganic and organic dust during manual harvest operations of California citrus and table grapes
Text: Personal exposures to inhalable dust and respirable dust were measured five times over a 4-month period of harvesting season
Text: We analyzed components of the dust samples for mineralogy , respirable quartz , endotoxin , and total and culturable microorganisms
Text: Workers manually harvesting were exposed to a complex mixture of inorganic and organic dust
Text: Exposures for citrus harvest had geometric means of 39.7 mg/m3 for inhalable dust and 1.14 mg/m3 for respirable dust
Text: These exposures were significantly higher than those for table grape operations and exceeded the threshold limit value for inhalable dust and respirable quartz
Text: Exposures for table grape operations were lower than the threshold limit value , except inhalable dust exposure during leaf pulling
Text: Considered independently , exposures to inhalable dust and respirable quartz in citrus harvest may be high enough to cause respiratory health effects
Text: The degree of vigorous contact with foliage appeared to be a significant determining factor of exposures in manual harvesting .
Text: METHODS
Text: Experimental Design
Text: Personal exposure samples were collected and analyzed from two groups of agricultural field workers in the San Joaquin Valley of California
Text: The first group was involved in citrus harvest in Tulare County
Text: The second group was involved in table grape operations in Kern County
Text: Airborne dust exposures were measured for a total of 5 working days for each crop over the peak labor months of June through September 1992
Text: Sampling dates were approximately 1 month apart , except in September , when 2 consecutive days were monitored for each crop
Text: Tasks were selected to be representative of those performed by labor crews throughout the summer months
Text: For citrus , harvesting was the task measured for all five sampling visits
Text: For table grapes , the task on the first sampling visit was leaf pulling
Text: harvesting table grapes was conducted for the remaining four sampling visits
Text: For both crops , 14 workers were monitored during each visit
Text: Ten workers were fitted with respirable dust samplers to measure respirable dust and respirable quartz exposures
Text: Four workers were fitted with inhalable dust samplers to measure inhalable dust , endotoxin , and total bacteria and fungi exposures .
Text: Selection of Farm Locations and Worker Participants
Text: A fruit packing company in Tulare County provided access to all the citrus harvest sites
Text: A producer of table grapes in Kern County provided access to all the sites visited for table grape production
Text: Tulare and Kern counties were chosen because they are very significant producers of citrus and table grapes , and because they were the main field locations in a previous epidemiologic study that had found reduced forced vital capacity in grape harvest workers
Text: From each farm location , and on each sampling date , a convenience sample of individual farm workers was used , based on the willingness of individuals to participate
Text: No attempt was made to follow the same individuals throughout the study .
Text: Collection of Samples
Text: We collected inhalable dust , endotoxin , and total bacteria and fungi samples with an open face polystyrene cassette of 37 mm diameter with a 0.4 μm pore size polycarbonate filter , and a pump flow rate of 2.0 L/min
Text: The samples were collected in the breathing zone
Text: Sampling times for endotoxin , total bacteria and fungi , and inhalable dust were regulated with the goal of collecting approximately 1 mg of total mass
Text: On the first sampling day , eight of nine inhalable samples exceeded a total mass of 2 mg
Text: The concentrations for that day are probably conservative because some of the sampled material may have not adhered to the filters
Text: Except on the first sampling day , samples were less than 2 mg of total mass
Text: About half of the samples had less than 1 mg of total mass
Text: For citrus harvest a typical sample time was 15 min
Text: For table grape operations a typical sample time was 1 hour
Text: For respirable dust and respirable quartz samples , a 10-mm nylon cyclone was used with a 5 μm pore size PVC filter , and a pump flow rate of 1.7 L/min
Text: Respirable fraction samples were typically collected for 6 to 8 hours .
Text: A two-stage Andersen sampler ( Graseby Andersen , Atlanta , Ga. ) was used to collect culturable airborne bioaerosol samples within 2 feet of employees
Text: Fungal samples were collected on Sabouraud media
Text: Bacterial samples were collected on trypticase soy agar with 5 % sheep 's blood ( TSA II )
Text: Sampling times averaged 30 sec
Text: One sample and one duplicate ( consisting of two plates each ) were collected daily for bacteria and for fungi
Text: Field blanks were generated daily , and one laboratory blank was generated per medium batch .
Text: We collected dust from leaf surfaces by agitating the foliage in front of a canopy connected to a high-volume pump ( Gast Model 1532 , SKC , Fullerton , Calif . )
Text: This approach was used to provide sufficient dust samples for chemical characterization of the bulk dust
Text: The pump was operated at 30 L/min and was fitted with a 20 cm × 25 cm polycarbonate filter with 0.4 μm pore size
Text: All dust shaken off the leaves was collected on the filter
Text: Sampling time was approximately 90 min per sample , with two samples collected from each farm .
Text: Four surface soil samples were collected daily
Text: Two samples each were collected from under plants and from rows between plants
Text: Sample locations were selected to represent the limits of the area worked by employees on that day
Text: For example , samples would be collected from the northeast corner and the southwest corner of the section of orchard or vineyard being harvested
Text: Samples were collected with a stainless steel trowel from approximately 0–3 inches below the soil surface and placed in plastic bags .
Text: Analysis of Samples
Text: Inhalable Dust , Respirable Dust , and Respirable Quartz
Text: The filters were pre- and postweighed , controlling for moisture effects , to determine sample weight and dust concentration
Text: Quantitative analyses of respirable quartz were performed using powder X-ray diffraction
Text: Filters for respirable dust were ashed in a muffle furnace , and the residue from the filter was transferred to a 25 mm diameter silver membrane filter
Text: The silver membrane was step-scanned from about 26 to 27 degrees 2 theta ( quartz diffraction maximum ) using a Diano XRD-8000 ( Waburn , Mass . )
Text: The diffraction peak area for each sample was compared with the quartz peak area from a set of prepared standards ( 20 to 200 μg quartz per filter ) to determine the mass of quartz and the corresponding percentage in the original dust ( Method 7500 )
Text: ( 11 )
Text: Dust from Foliage and Soil
Text: Two samples each of the citrus dust and the grape dust were analyzed for total sulfur content by inductively coupled plasma spectrometry ( Perkin Elmer Optima 3000 DV ICP , Perkin Elmer , Shelton , Conn . )
Text: The mineral composition of the foliar total dusts was determined by X-ray diffraction ( Siemens D5000 X-Ray Diffractometer , Bruker AXS , Madison , Wis. ) after the dusts were ashed in a muffle furnace and transferred to silver membranes
Text: Total foliar dust samples were dry-sieved to obtain a < 10 μm diameter size fraction for particle component analysis .
Text: For particle component analysis , an aliquot of the sample was ashed in a Denton PE-120 Plasma Asher ( Cherry Hill , N.J. ) for 24 hours to remove all organic matter , and the residue was made up to 100 mL with double distilled water with a drop of Aerosol OT
Text: After sonication , aliquots were filtered through 0.1 μm pore size polycarbonate filters and mounted on carbon planchettes
Text: Using a scanning electron microscope in back-scattered electronic-imaging mode an average of 1000 or more particles in each sample were randomly analyzed for elemental analysis using an energy dispersive X-ray analyzer ( Kevex 7000 EDXA System , Kevex International , Foster City , Calif. ) at 1000× according to the methods described by Stettler et al
Text: Soil particle size-distribution ( % sand , silt , and clay ) of Na-dispersed samples was determined by the standard pipette and sieving method
Text: Airborne Endotoxin
Text: Filters with collected dusts were analyzed for endotoxin content by means of the kinetic chromogenic modification of the Limulus amebocyte lysate assay ( Kinetic-QCL
Text: BioWhittaker , Walkersville , Md. ) as previously described
Text: Sterile nonpyrogenic plasticware was used throughout the analyses
Text: Each filter was extracted separately in 10 mL of sterile nonpyrogenic water ( LAL Reagent Water
Text: BioWhittaker ) by rocking at room temperature for 60 min
Text: The extracts were decanted into separate plastic tubes , centrifuged for 10 min at 1000 × g , and the resulting supernatant fluids were assayed in duplicate for the presence of endotoxin
Text: The results are reported in terms of endotoxin units ( EU ) per milligram of dust , and calculations were made to express the airborne levels in terms of EU per cubic meter of air .
Text: Airborne Total Bacteria and Fungi
Text: Total culturable and nonculturable bacteria and fungi were quantified using the fluorescence microscopy NFE method
Text: For each filter collected for total fungi and bacteria , the collected microorganisms were extracted by washing three times with a filter sterilized aqueous solution of 0.01 % Tween 80 and 1 % formaldehyde
Text: For each washing , 1.5 mL of wash solution was injected into the support pad through the outlet connection of the cassette , after which the connection was plugged
Text: Five mL of the wash solution was pipetted into the inlet hold , after which the cassette was replugged and vigorously shaken on a shaking table for 5 min
Text: The cassette was then opened and the suspension removed with a syringe
Text: The three wash suspensions were pooled , and serial dilutions of this solution were filtered through black polycarbonate filters
Text: The filter and the adhered microorganisms were stained for 2 min using a filtered acridine orange solution ( 0.1 mg/mL , pH = 7.2 in phosphate buffer ) .
Text: The filters were removed , dried in a laminar flow hood , and mounted on a microscope slide with Cargile A immersion oil and a cover-slip
Text: The number of microorganisms on the filter surface was counted at a magnification of 1000× with an epifluorescence microscope
Text: Spores and bacteria were counted until all organisms in 40 high-power fields had been evaluated .
Text: Airborne Culturable Bacteria and Fungi
Text: The collected culture plates were incubated at 30°C and 25°C for bacterial plates and fungal plates , respectively
Text: Colonies were counted using a colony counter
Text: Results were expressed as colony forming units and were adjusted for coincident collection .
Text: Determinants of Respirable Quartz Exposure Concentrations Across Occupations in Denmark , 2018
Text: ABSTRACT
Text: Background
Text: High concentrations of respirable quartz have been reported from workers in construction , foundries , and quarries
Text: Current exposure concentrations in prevalent but presumably lower exposed occupations have been less examined
Text: We aimed to quantify current exposure concentrations of respirable dust and quartz across prevalent occupations and to identify determinants of respirable quartz exposure across these occupations .
Text: Methods
Text: One hundred and eighty-nine full-shift personal samples of respirable dust of workers within 11 occupations in Denmark were sampled during 2018
Text: Respirable dust was determined gravimetrically and analysed for quartz content with infrared spectrometry
Text: Determinants for respirable quartz exposure , i.e
Text: use of power tools , outdoor or indoor location , and percentage of quartz in respirable dust , were analysed in linear mixed effect models .
Text: Results
Text: The overall geometric means ( geometric standard deviations ) for respirable dust and quartz were 216 µg m−3 ( 4.42 ) and 16 µg m−3 ( 4.07 ) , respectively
Text: The highest quartz concentrations were observed among stone cutters and carvers [ 93 µg m−3 ( 3.47 ) ] , and metal melters and casters [ 61 µg m−3 ( 1.71 ) ]
Text: Use of power tools increased exposure concentrations of quartz by a factor of 3.5
Text: Occupations explained 27 % , companies within occupations 28 % , and differences between workers within companies within occupations 14 % of the variability in quartz concentrations
Text: Thirty percent was due to day-to-day variability in exposure concentrations
Text: In total , 19 % of the variation in quartz concentration could be explained by type of tool , indoor/outdoor location , and percentage of quartz in respirable dust .
Text: Conclusion
Text: Current exposure concentrations are generally low , but some occupations in this study had average exposure concentrations to respirable quartz above the ACGIH threshold limit value of 25 µg m−3
Text: Preventive measures to lower excess risk of quartz-related diseases among these workers are still needed
Text: In terms of preventive strategies , use of power tools and quartz content of used materials were identified as main determinants of exposure
Text: Lowering of exposures will be most efficient when focussed on these major determinants , e.g
Text: tool dust control with water , dust extraction , and use of low quartz content materials .
Text: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Text: Companies and participants
Text: Based on the prevalence of occupations in Denmark with expected quartz exposure ( BGIA , 2008
Text: Peters et al. , 2011
Text: IARC , 2012 ) , we identified companies employing construction- , metal- , and concrete workers and farmers
Text: Occupations were classified based on the four-digit level of the Danish version of the International Standard Classification of Occupations , ISCO-88 ( ILO , 2004 )
Text: Industry was classified at two-digit level of the European classification of industries , NACE vers.2 ( The European Parliament and Council of the European Union , 2006 ) ( Table 1 , Supplementary Table S1 )
Text: We prioritized inclusion of companies of different sizes , and when feasible companies with employees from more than one relevant occupation located in the eastern part of Jutland
Text: A total of 38 companies were approached
Text: 15 large companies with more than 100 employees and 23 small companies with less than 100 employees
Text: In total 24 companies ( 63 % ) agreed to participate of which 5 employed workers from more than one relevant occupation
Text: Sixty percent of the large companies and 65 % of the small companies accepted the invitation
Text: Farmers were contacted through a farmers’ trade associations
Text: however , no farmers were recruited .
Text: Managers at the worksites were instructed to select up to eight employees with work tasks representative for the targeted occupations .
Text: Sampling and analytical method
Text: On the measurement day , participants filled in a questionnaire about primary task , tools , or construction machines used , whether their work location was indoor or outdoor , and use of a respirator
Text: We conducted full-shift measurements
Text: however , pumps were turned off during breaks lasting more than 15 min
Text: Measurements with sampling time below 4 h were excluded
Text: All companies were asked to participate in a second measuring round
Text: If they agreed , repeated measurements were carried out on study participants who remained at the worksite
Text: All measurements were carried out by the same technician between April and December 2018 .
Text: Respirable dust was collected on 25-mm PVC filters using a conductive plastic sampler with a respirable dust cyclone ( SKC LTD conductive plastic cyclone ) connected to SKC AirChek XR5000 portable pump ( SKC Inc. , Eighty-Four , PA ) calibrated at a flow rate of 2.2 l/min
Text: The cassette was attached to the upper part of the participant’s chest within the breathing zone .
Text: Respirable dust was determined gravimetrically
Text: Filters were conditioned for a minimum of 24 h ( 22°C , 45 % relative humidity ) before weighing using a Mettler UMT2 analytical scale ( Mettler-Toledo Ltd , Greifensee , Switzerland ) with 0.1-mg precision
Text: One field blank was included per visit ( n = 45 )
Text: The lower limit of detection ( LOD ) for respirable dust was calculated as three times the Standard deviation ( SD ) of the weight changes of the field blanks , corresponding to a concentration of 24 µg m−3 , when assuming 8-h measurements .
Text: Quartz was determined by Fourier transform infrared spectrometry , in accordance with MDHS 101/2 ( HSE , 2014 )
Text: The analytical level of quantification for quartz was 10 µg , assuming 8-h measurements correspond to a concentration of 9 µg m−3 .
Text: Statistical analysis
Text: Respirable dust and respirable quartz concentrations were log normally distributed , assuming values below LOD followed the same distribution
Text: Hence , statistical analyses were performed using log-transformed values
Text: We used mixed effects Tobit models ( metobit , Stata ) for interval censored data
Text: All left censored values ( values below LOD ) were assumed to be in an interval between ( -∞ ) and the LOD ( Hughes , 1999
Text: StataCorp. , 2019 ) .
Text: In the applied mixed effect models , worker , company , and occupation were included as random effects , and tool , location , and percentage of quartz in respirable dust as fixed effects
Text: β-coefficients are displayed as Exp β with 95 % confidence intervals ( CI )
Text: Geometric standard deviation factor ( GSD ) was calculated as exp ( √σ2wY+σ2bY ) , where σ2wY= within-worker variance and σ2bY = between-worker variance
Text: The occupational exposure limit ( OEL ) in Denmark and several European countries is 100 µg m−3 ( The European Parliament and Council of the European Union , 2017 ) , and we calculated the exceedance fraction above as P [ Z < ln ( OEL ) −ln ( GM ) ln ( GSD ) ] .
Text: If an occupational group was represented by less than 10 persons on ISCO-88 major group 4 level , it was merged with similar occupations on the corresponding ISCO-88 major group 3 level
Text: Tool was categorized into no tool , hand tools , power tools , and operating construction machines
Text: Location was dichotomized into primarily working inside or outside ( Table 1 , Supplementary Table S1 )
Text: The percentage of quartz in respirable dust was imputed for quartz measurements below LOD ( 38 % )
Text: For the majority of missing values , we used the median of the percentage of quartz from other workers doing the same job at the same company
Text: For the remaining seven missing values , where none of the co-workers had detectable values of quartz , we used the median percentage from all workers in the same job and company using the estimated LOD value of quartz .
Text: All analyses were carried out using Stata , version 16 and 17 .
Text: RESULTS
Text: We performed 194 measurements on 143 participants
Text: One measurement was lost during transportation and four with a sampling time of less than 4 h did not fulfil our inclusion criteria and were excluded , leaving 189 measurements from 140 participants for further analyses
Text: The median sampling time was 428 min , with an interquartile range of 367–456 min
Text: Repeated measurements were available for 35 % of the participants , with a median duration between the two measurements of 91 days , interquartile range 84–125 days .
Text: All together 15 % of workers ( 21 participants ) reported use of respirators at some point during the day , with missing information from 5 % of the measurements
Text: For nine participants using respirators , quartz concentrations were below the LOD , and the range in concentrations among workers using respirators was from 11 to 1083 µg m−3
Text: The majority ( 68 % ) of the respirator users reported using power tools , 45 % were employed in a large company ( < 100 employees ) , and 55 % in a smaller company .
Text: Five percent of the respirable dust measurements and 38 % of the quartz measurements were below LOD ( Table 1 )
Text: Thirteen percent of all measurements were above the OEL
Text: Measured quartz concentrations ranged from values < LOD to 1083 µg m−3
Text: Stone cutters and carvers were the only occupation having measurements with concentrations above 200 µg m−3 and had a probability of exceedance of 48 %
Text: Construction workers ( bricklayers , stonemasons , and other building frame workers )
Text: mineral or stone processing-plant operators , and metal melters and casters had lower quartz concentrations and probability of exceedance between 14 and 18 % ( Table 1 ) .
Text: The geometric mean , GM ( geometric standard deviation , GSD ) for respirable dust exposure concentration was 216 µg m−3 ( 4.42 )
Text: Highest exposure concentrations were found among demolition workers and scaffolding fitters ( included in the building frame workers category ) , with a GM of 741 µg m−3 ( 2.83 ) , metal melters and casters with a GM of 719 µg m−3 ( 1.97 ) , and blacksmiths with a GM of 718 µg m−3 ( 2.50 ) ( Table 1 ) .
Text: The GM ( GSD ) of overall quartz exposure concentration was 16 µg m−3 ( 4.07 )
Text: Highest concentrations were observed among stonecutters and carvers , GM of 93 µg m−3 ( 3.47 ) , and metal melters and casters , GM of 61 µg m−3 ( 1.71 ) ( Table 1 )
Text: Percentage of quartz in respirable dust varied from 6 to 30 % across occupations
Text: Highest percentage were seen among bricklayers and stonemasons ( Table 1 ) .
Text: Use of hand or power tools compared with no tools increased quartz exposure concentrations , e.g
Text: use of power tools resulted in a 3.5 times higher exposure [ exp ( β ) = 3.46 ( 1.66–7.21 ) ] ( Table 2 )
Text: The quartz content was also an important determinant , with 3 percentage increase in quartz exposure concentration for each percent increase in quartz content in respirable dust .
Text: Of the total variance , occupations explained 27 % , companies within occupations 29 % , and workers within a company within an occupation 14 % of the variability in quartz concentrations
Text: Thirty percent was due to day-to-day variability in quartz concentrations
Text: Including tool and location as fixed effects into the model explained 13 % of the total variability , primarily decreasing the variability between workers within companies and occupations ( 35 % explained )
Text: When percentage of quartz in respirable dust was added , the fixed effects explained 19 % of the total variability , 38 % of the variability between occupations , 14 % between companies within occupation , and 29 % between workers within companies and occupations ( Table 3 ) .
Text: Mass , surface area and number metrics in diesel occupational exposure assessment
Text: ABSTRACT
Text: While diesel aerosol exposure assessment has traditionally been based on the mass concentration metric , recent studies have suggested that particle number and surface area concentrations may be more health-relevant
Text: In this study , we evaluated the exposures of three occupational groups-bus drivers , parking garage attendants , and bus mechanics-using the mass concentration of elemental carbon ( EC ) as well as surface area and number concentrations
Text: These occupational groups are exposed to mixtures of diesel and gasoline exhaust on a regular basis in various ratios
Text: The three groups had significantly different exposures to workshift TWA EC with the highest levels observed in the bus garage mechanics and the lowest levels in the parking ramp booth attendants
Text: In terms of surface area , parking ramp attendants had significantly greater exposures than bus garage mechanics , who in turn had significantly greater exposures than bus drivers
Text: In terms of number concentrations , the exposures of garage mechanics exceeded those of ramp booth attendants by a factor of 5-6
Text: Depending on the exposure metric chosen , the three occupational groups had quite different exposure rankings
Text: This illustrates the importance of the choice of exposure metric in epidemiological studies
Text: If these three occupational groups were part of an epidemiological study , depending on the metric used , they may or may not be part of the same similarly exposed group ( SEG )
Text: The exposure rankings ( e.g. , low , medium , or high ) of the three groups also changes with the metric used
Text: If the incorrect metric is used , significant misclassification errors may occur .
Text: METHODS
Text: A
Text: Instrumentation
Text: The instrument suite used in this project enabled aerosol from < 10 nm to 10 mm to be characterized and was uniquely capable of characterizing exposure .
Text: i
Text: Mass concentration ( elemental carbon sampling )
Text: Elemental carbon ( EC ) accounts for a significant fraction of DPM emissions , and is readily detectable by thermal-optical analysis
Text: This analytical method is described in the NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods
Text: The personal sampling train for EC samples consisted of a 10 mm MSA cyclone , 37 mm pre-fired ultra pure , quartz fiber , Pallflex filter held in a 3-piece 37 mm cassette , and a MSA ELF pump
Text: Pumps were calibrated with a Gilibrator primary flow device ( electronic bubble meter ) and operated at 3.0 LPM so that the collected mass of EC was greater than the limit of detection for the method
Text: At this flow rate , the cyclone had a 50 % cut-point of 2.85 mm
Text: The minimum sampling time was six hours
Text: Diesel and spark-ignition aerosols are nearly all less than 1.0 mm in diameter , and thus the cyclone collected virtually the entire aerosol mass .
Text: Quartz fiber filters are known to adsorb organic vapors during the sampling process
Text: A correction factor was estimated for this adsorption by using dynamic blanks
Text: A Teflon filter ( Zefluor ) was placed on top of the Pallflex filter in the three piece cassette and samples were collected as discussed above
Text: The Teflon filter adsorbs little organic vapor but effectively removes particulate matter
Text: The organic vapor passes through and adsorbs on the Pallflex filter , which is analyzed by the NIOSH 5040 method for EC
Text: It is believed that the Pallflex filter reaches equilibrium with the adsorbed organic material thus allowing for a correction factor to be estimated
Text: In addition to dynamic blanks , a limited number of field blanks were submitted for analysis .
Text: ii
Text: Surface area concentration ( Diffusion Charger—DC )
Text: The diffusion charger measures the total active surface area of particulate matter
Text: Positively charged ions are produced by a glow discharge , forming in the neighborhood of a very thin wire
Text: These ions attach themselves to the sampled aerosol stream with a certain probability
Text: The charged aerosol particles are then collected on a filter
Text: The electric current flowing from the filter to ground potential is measured and is proportional to the number of ions attached to the particles
Text: For particles in the free molecular range , the attachment is proportional to the surface area of the particles , but is independent of the composition of the particles
Text: Siegmann et al
Text: contend that the DC measures the so-called ‘‘active surface’’ in the size range from slightly above ten to a few hundred nm
Text: The active surface is the effective surface area available for mass transfer in a kinetically limited situation and should be appropriate for describing the gas to particle mass transfer taking place in a diluting exhaust plume
Text: However , for particles ~1 mm , the instrument response scales as particle diameter , and thus the relationship with surface area is lost .
Text: A portable DC ( EcoChem Analytics LQ1-DC ) was used in this project
Text: It was set to average data over a 10 s period , covering a range from 0 to 4000 fA with a resolution of 1 fA and a flow rate of 1.0 L min-1 .
Text: iii
Text: Surface area concentration ( Photoelectric Aerosol Sensor—PAS )
Text: The PAS responds to photoemitting substances on the surface of aerosol particles
Text: Ultraviolet irradiation of the sampled aerosol leads to the emission of photoelectrons from surface material that readily undergoes photoemission
Text: The remaining positively charged aerosol particles are separated from the electrons and collected on a filter connected to an electrometer
Text: The measured current is a function of the UV irradiation wavelength and intensity , the total available surface area and the photoemission properties of the surface materials
Text: Commercially available instruments usually use a wavelength of 222 nm
Text: Diesel accumulation mode particles strongly respond to the PAS .
Text: The PAS was originally promoted as a monitor for surfacebound polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons ( PAHs )
Text: Surface bound PAHs have a high photoelectric ( PE ) yield , causing a high PAS response
Text: DPM found in the accumulation mode consists primarily of EC , and has a significantly lower PE yield , which results in a more moderate PAS response
Text: For diesel accumulation mode particles , the PAS signal correlates with the accumulation mode surface area concentration
Text: In mixed urban aerosols , on the other hand , where the PAH surface concentration ( for example from spark ignition engines ) may be much higher , the high PE yield of the PAH dominates the PAS response
Text: Therefore , PAS signals can only be quantitatively interpreted in a certain context
Text: Nevertheless , PAS signal observations are useful for monitoring of relative changes using the measured electrometer response ( usually fA units )
Text: These values are corrected for lamp fluctuations , which enables good instrument-to-instrument comparability in commercially available instruments .
Text: A portable PAS ( EcoChem Analytics PAS 2000 CE ) was used in this project
Text: It was set to average data over a 10 s period , covering a range from 0 to 4000 fA with a resolution of 1 fA ( estimated accuracy of 2 fA )
Text: The PAS limit of detection is about 10 fA , and it has a flow rate of 1.0 L min 1 .
Text: iv
Text: Number concentration ( Ultrafine Condensation Particle Counter—UCPC )
Text: The UCPC ( Model 3025A , TSI Inc. ) was used to obtain total particle number concentration
Text: The UCPC counts particles in the range of 3–1000 nm , and operates by saturating the carrier air stream with a butyl alcohol vapor
Text: The air stream is cooled which produces a supersaturation and causes vapor to condense onto the particles
Text: The particles then rapidly grow to an optically detectable size ( 10–12 mm ) .
Text: v
Text: Size distribution ( Scanning Mobility Particle Sizer— SMPS )
Text: The SMPS consists of a TSI 3071A Electrostatic Classifier and a TSI 3025A Ultrafine Condensation Particle Counter ( UCPC )
Text: It was used to classify particles by an electrical mobility equivalent diameter
Text: The SMPS was configured to cover the range of 8 to 300 nm in the high flow mode ( 10 L min-11 sheath air flow and 1.0 L min-1 aerosol flow )
Text: Data were collected using 60 s up scan and 30 s down scan times
Text: Data were analyzed using version 3.2 of the TSI SMPS software
Text: SMPS data presented here include the integrated total number concentration , surface area concentration , and geometric mean diameter
Text: The SMPS active surface is calculated using expressions given by Pandis et al. , Kasper et al. , and Kasper et al
Text: assuming spherical particles and that the species charging the particles is a hydrated proton which has a mean free path of 14.5 nm.51 This calculation should simulate the response of the DC although it does not include size dependent losses in either instrument .
Text: B
Text: Sampling strategy
Text: i
Text: Sampling locations and occupational categories
Text: The Twin Cities Metropolitan and the University of Minnesota transit systems together offer an environment in which both diesel and gasoline powered vehicles operate on a regular basis in various mixtures from almost all gasoline vehicles to nearly all diesel-fueled buses
Text: This provided a unique opportunity to measure the different exposure scenarios .
Text: Area and personal samples were collected depending upon the specific location and situation
Text: Personal samples were collected in or near the breathing zone of the worker over a full work-shift
Text: The PAS , DC , SMPS and UCPC were used to collect area samples as near to the breathing zone of the worker as possible
Text: These data were collected in near real-time and downloaded to a computer .
Text: Three occupational categories were selected for monitoring : bus drivers ( personal samples ) , parking garage attendants ( personal and area samples ) , and bus mechanics ( personal and area samples )
Text: These were selected because they provided a mix of exposure scenarios based on the mix of gasoline and diesel exhaust in each scenario as well as the age of the aerosol , and they are representative of workers employed in the transportation industry
Text: Table 1 summarizes the number of different types of measurements and their sampling durations for the three occupational categories
Text: Table 1 shows the number of workshifts
Text: For each workshift , there will be a large number of measurements gathered depending on the sampling frequency of the real-time instruments , and a single workshift average is then calculated ( shown in Table 2 )
Text: For example , for DC , Table 1 shows that 6 workshift average measurements were obtained in bus drivers ( 3 + 2 + 1 )
Text: In Table 2 , we see the summary statistics for the workshift whose average sampling time is given
Text: We also see that these 6 workshifts correspond to 5595 10-second average measurements .
Text: A chemical mass balance method has been used to determine the relative contributions of specific emission sources to the total mass in atmospheric particulate samples ( Cass et al 1984
Text: Waalkes and Ward 1994
Text: Schauer et al 1996
Text: Watson et al 1998 )
Text: In these tests , ambient air- borne EC appeared to be most closely related to diesel emissions ( Cass et al 1984
Text: Cass and Gray 1995
Text: Birch andCary 1996 )
Text: However , ambient air exposures are complex , with many sources of air contaminants , including EC .
Text: Source apportionment based on details from the chemical mass balance method makes it possible to determine how much EC is coming from diesel engines
Text: For example , diesel vehicles emit large amounts of EC , only small amounts of cholestane and related compounds , and no levoglucosan ( a plant sugar ) , whereas gasoline vehicles emit relatively large amounts of cholestane compounds , little EC , and no levoglucosan
Text: softwood combustion releases relatively large amounts of levoglucosan and moderate amounts of EC and cholestane
Text: An air sample showing large amounts of EC , small amounts of cholestane and related compounds , and small amounts of levoglucosan would implicate diesel emissions as the main contributors with small amounts of gasoline vehicle emissions and softwood smoke included .
Text: On the basis of source apportionment findings and exposure data from other investigators , we chose EC as our primary marker of diesel emissions , and OC and PM2.5 as markers to track exposures to other general air contaminants
Text: The quality of EC as a diesel marker in occupational settings varies because proximity to the source is an important determinant of exposure intensity
Text: For workers whose jobs bring them close to operating diesels , diesel exhaust is a major component of the air contaminants soEC would be a good marker of exposure
Text: For workers with no nearby diesel sources , EC may be a poor marker because more than half of the EC in the ambient air may come from other combustion sources such as home heating or wood fires ( Cass et al 1984
Text: Waalkes and Ward 1994
Text: Watson et al 1998 )
Text: Combining source apportionment with use of EC as a marker compensates for the lack of a unique marker of diesel emissions .
Text: Independent of its application as a marker for the quantity of diesel emissions in the air , the suitability of EC as a marker for human carcinogens in diesel exhaust is difficult to assess
Text: It is not clear whether EC itself is a human carcinogen , or the organic compounds in diesel exhaust are the primary carcinogens , or EC and OC together are the agents of cancer risk
Text: No carcinogenic pollutant is unique to diesel emissions
Text: rather , all of the common combustion sources overlap with diesel emissions
Text: The relative concentrations vary , but virtually all are present .
Text: Some of the goals of the feasibility study were to determine the applicability of potential sampling methods , to verify that personal exposure monitoring is feasible , and to obtain limited data on current exposures
Text: We used real- time and integrative sampling to obtain personal , area , and source data for PM2.5
Text: Particulate samples were analyzed to measure concentrations of EC and OC .
Text: Exposure Assessment Methods
Text: Exposure Assessment Methods
Text: Personal exposure to PM2.5 was measured by filter sam pling using the Personal Environmental Monitor ( PEM ) ( SKC , Eighty Four PA ) , which has a small impactor and 37- mm Teflon filter with a pore diameter of 0.2 µm
Text: Mass col- lected on filters was determined by gravimetric analysis using an analytic balance ( Micro-Gravimetric M5 , Mettler Instruments Corp , Hightstown NJ ) and Pallflex Teflon 37-mm fiber filters ( Pall Corp , East Hills NY ) , and Tissue-Quartz 25-mm fiber filters ( URG , Chapel Hill NC )
Text: The filters were weighed after humidity equilibrium was attained ( after at least 24 hours ) in a chamber
Text: At the end of sampling , the filter was taken back to the laboratory
Text: After humidity equilibrium was attained , the filter was reweighed to determine weight gain
Text: A second set of PM2.5 samples was collected using a similar sampler with a Tis- sueQuartz filter
Text: These samples were analyzed for EC and OC using the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health ( NIOSH ) 5040 thermo-optical method ( Birch and Cary 1996
Text: Cassinelli and O’Connor 1998 ) at the laboratory of Dr James Schauer , University of Wisconsin , Madison .
Text: Real-time measurements of PM2.5 were made with the DustTrak ( TSI , Shoreview MN ) using laser light scatter into detect airborne particles after passage through an impactor that removes particles larger than 2.5 µm in diameter
Text: Concurrently with the DustTrak monitor , a Q-Trak ( TSI ) was used to obtain real-time data on carbon monoxide ( CO ) , carbon dioxide ( CO2 ) , temperature , and relative humidity
Text: The Q-Trak uses a set of physicochem- ical sensors
Text: The sampler inlet was placed on the back of the seat , at shoulder level , next to the driver , so the sample represented the air quality in the center of the cab .
Text: Large-volume integrative samples for detailed chemical analysis were collected using a 47-mm TissueQuartz filter sampler with a large cyclone separator ( less than 2.5-µm- diameter cutoff ) operated at 16.7 L/min for 8 to 12 hours
Text: Gas chromatography/mass spectroscopy ( GC/MS ) was used by Dr Schauer’s laboratory to analyze these samples for a wide range of specific organic compounds ( Schauer et al 1996 )
Text: This analysis involved extensive sample preparation , including spiking the filters with 7 deuterated internal recovery standards , and 5 extraction steps .
Text: Extracts were combined and reduced in volume , and finally half of the combined extract was derivatized with diazomethane to esterify organic acids
Text: Both the derivatized and underivatized extracts were analyzed on aGC/MS ( GC model 5890 and MS model 5972 , Hewlett-Packard ) , using a capillary column 30 m × 0.25 mm in diameter ( HP-1701 )
Text: More than 100 compounds are quantified with a relative error of 20 %
Text: The following chemical compound groups are evaluated : n-alkanes , polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons , substituted phenols , guaiacol and related compounds , syringol and related compounds , n-alkanoic acids , n-alkenoic acids , alkane dicarboxylic acids , aromatic carboxylic acids , resin acids , levoglucosan and other sugars , and other organic compounds
Text: The cost and complexity of the analysis limit its application to com- posited samples from work locations where the types of sources are likely to be approximately constant .
Text: Exposure Measurement Strategy
Text: Testing was conducted at 2 large terminals in the Atlanta area during October 1999
Text: In total , 45 PM2.5 personal samples ( with EC and OC measurements ) and 14 DustTrak personal samples were collected for forklift operators , mechanics , hostlers , long-haul drivers , local ( P & D ) drivers , and dockworkers directly involved in daily terminal activity
Text: For area samples , 90 PM2.5 ( with EC andOC ) , 7 source apportionment ( later composited for anaysis ) , and 58 DustTrak samples were collected from the loading dock , shop , fueling lane , and clerk’s office
Text: An upwind background sample , called the “yard sample , ” was also collected at each site
Text: Sampling methods were compared by hanging several different samplers side-by- side in different areas
Text: Concurrent with the gravimetric monitoring , real-time monitoring of airborne particles was done with a DustTrak to obtain 1-minute averages of light- scattering respirable PM2.5
Text: One-minute averages of CO , CO2 , temperature , and relative humidity were also measured with the Q-Trak
Text: Exposures also were assessed at 4 small rural terminals in New England by sampling in the dock area and upwind in the yard in April to May 2000 with the collection of 18 PM2.5 , 14 EC and OC , and 16 DustTrak area samples .
Text: The vast majority of personal samples and area samples were collected over 8 to 12 hours
Text: A limited number of side-by-side personal samples also were collected by equipping a worker with 2 personal samplers to assess the relationship between URG personal measurements of EC and OC and PEM gravimetric measurements for personal sampling
Text: The area samples were taken at similar locations in the terminal area , 5 feet from the deck level , with 4 different collecting devices ( size-selective samplers ) : Dust-Trak , Q-Trak , personal sampler , and PEM .
Text: Previous NIOSH Studies
Text: In 1988 and 1989 NIOSH sponsored Health Hazard Evaluation studies by Zaebst and coworkers to characterize exposures to diesel emissions in the trucking industry ( summarized in Zaebst et al 1990 )
Text: A total of 327 personal and area samples were collected in 7 large truck freight terminals
Text: These data represent a critical historical database on conditions in the late 1980s
Text: The individual data points given in the report appendices are an important resource .
Text: We also used the NIOSH studies to help assess other sources of exposure variability so that we could identify current and historical factors that will define differences in exposure across the industry .
Text: STATISTICAL ANALYSIS
Text: Smoking and Work History Questionnaire
Text: Chi-square tests were performed to compare questionnaire respondents and nonrespondents and various parameters describing smoking behavior by job title .
Text: Means were compared using t tests
Text: Logistic regression models were used to identify predictors of current- smoking or ever-smoking status
Text: Linear regression methods were used to assess predictors of average cigarette consumption .
Text: Exposure Assessment
Text: Results of the environmental sampling surveys were expressed as geometric mean ( GM ) and geometric standard deviation ( GSD ) because the distribution of sampling results is approximately log-normal
Text: The results of real- time sampling from the DustTrak ( plots of PM2.5 level versus time ) are also presented for various locations
Text: Analysis of variance was used to compare between-terminal variations
Text: Although some of the limited data collected in this study was evaluated statistically , the focus was on the feasibility of monitoring exposure
Text: The scope of the project was limited by the sponsor
Text: As a result , the analysis of measurement error is based primarily on published data and NIOSH Health Hazard Evaluation Reports .
Text: Cancer Risk from Diesel Emissions Exposure in Central and Eastern Europe : A Feasibility Study
Text: ABSTRACT
Text: The objectives of this study were to assess the feasibility of enrolling a multicenter historical cohort of workers exposed to diesel emissions in central and eastern Europe ( the Czech Republic , Estonia , Hungary , Latvia , Lithuania , Poland , Russia , Slovakia , and Slovenia ) and of reconstructing past exposures for the cohort
Text: We developed a company questionnaire aimed at collecting standardized information to determine the number of workers who might be included in the cohort study and their exposures
Text: Our collaborators contacted companies that might participate in the study , provided a contact person with questionnaires to complete , and checked the completed questionnaires
Text: Data from company questionnaires were combined to estimate the size of the expected cohort in terms of exposure to diesel emissions and relevant agents
Text: We determined that it would be possible to enroll 3 multi-center cohorts of workers exposed to diesel exhaust in nonmetal mining , bus transport , and railway transport
Text: A total of 16 companies from 8 countries agreed in principle to participate in the proposed study , yielding an estimated total of 46,500 exposed workers with 295 deaths from lung cancer expected among them
Text: The study would have statistical power to assess a 30 % increase in lung cancer risk in each industry-specific cohort and a 15 % increase overall
Text: Groups of workers without exposure to diesel exhaust , from the same companies , would be available for internal comparisons
Text: The cohorts would be primarily composed of male workers .
Text: METHODS
Text: FEASIBILITY OF EPIDEMIOLOGIC STUDY
Text: Development of Company Questionnaire
Text: A company questionnaire was developed with the aim of collecting standardized information on the size and exposure of the groups of workers that might be included in the cohort study ( Appendix A )
Text: Special emphasis was put on the availability of information on exposure to agents other than diesel emissions
Text: The questionnaire was prepared at IARC , translated into the national language in each collaborating center , and back-translated into English at IARC to ensure the integrity of the original translation
Text: Contact with Possible Participating Companies
Text: The feasibility study was conducted in the Czech Republic , Estonia , Hungary , Latvia , Lithuania , Poland , Russia , Slovakia , and Slovenia
Text: Study collaborators are listed in the Acknowledgments section
Text: A similar study , not reported here , was conducted in Romania and Israel
Text: The feasibility study focused on 2 broadly defined groups of workers with potentially high exposure to diesel emissions : drivers ( ISCO 985 ) , mechanics ( ISCO 843 ) , and railway workers ( ISIC 71 ) in land transport
Text: and miners ( ISCO 71 ) in nonmetal mining
Text: ( The codes in parentheses are from the International Standard Classification of Occupations [ ISCO
Text: International Labour Office 1968 ] and the International Standard Industrial Classification [ ISIC
Text: United Nations 1971 ] )
Text: Each collaborating center identified and contacted companies in its study area that could include a substantial number of workers in the 2 categories defined above
Text: The initial contact aimed at identifying companies available to participate in the study , the approximate size of an exposed cohort and of another cohort not exposed to diesel emissions , the expected completeness of available employment records , and the available information about changes in sources of diesel emissions and the environment where the emissions occurred .
Text: Completion of Questionnaires
Text: The collaborators visited each company and presented the questionnaire to the contact persons
Text: The contact persons , who typically were production managers , technical engineers , or industrial hygienists , were in charge of completing the questionnaire
Text: They also provided additional information such as copies of sample pages of employment rosters and exposure records
Text: The completed questionnaires were returned to the collaborators , who checked the completeness and quality of the information collected
Text: Typically , the collaborators visited the company on several occasions to complete or clarify some aspects of the information collected
Text: The questionnaires were then translated into English , and copies were transferred to IARC and to the Institute of Occupational Medicine ( IOM , Edinburgh , UK ) .
Text: During the feasibility study and after completion of the company questionnaires , IARC epidemiologists visited each collaborating center
Text: they also visited some of the companies and discussed details about all companies with the contact persons
Text: In order to carry out personal exposure monitoring for selected occupations , chosen to represent a diverse range of exposure scenarios , IOM industrial hygienists visited four centers
Text: In addition , the hygienists assessed current work practices and conditions and verified or clarified the scope and quality of preexisting exposure-related information that would be required for the reconstruction of exposure histories .
Text: Estimate of Statistical Power of Cohort Study
Text: We derived from company questionnaires the approximate distribution by gender , age , and calendar period of first employment of workers in the companies retained for a full-scale study
