Text: We estimated the person-years of observation specific to gender , age , and calendar year , and applied the relevant incidence of lung cancer ( Parkin et al 1997 ) in order to estimate the number of cases of lung cancer expected in each cohort .
Text: Approximately 80 expected cases of lung cancer among exposed subjects would be necessary to obtain an 80 % power to detect as statistically significant ( at α level of 0.05 ) a 30 % increase in mortality based on external comparison ( Breslow and Day 1987 ) .
Text: OCCUPATIONAL EXPOSURE DATA
Text: Availability of Historical Exposure Data
Text: The availability and quality of historical exposure data was assessed from information gathered through company questionnaires and site visits by IARC epidemiologists and IOM industrial hygienists
Text: Copies of raw results of measurements were obtained whenever available
Text: Information about historical conditions and work practices was also obtained from the company representatives , who had many years of experience in the industry .
Text: Measurement of Current Exposures
Text: At the time of the survey , information about current work practices and conditions was obtained by observation and by discussion with company representatives
Text: Measurements of personal exposure to respirable dust and diesel exhaust were made using IOM respirable dust samplers fitted with foam inserts size-selective for particulate matter 10 µm or smaller in aerodynamic diameter ( PM10 )
Text: The IOM sampler cassettes were loaded with 25-mm quartz fiber filters , and the cassettes were weighed before the size-selective foam inserts were added
Text: Each sampler was positioned in the breathing zone by clipping it to the worker’s lapel
Text: The sampler was connected to a battery-operated pump by means of polyvinyl chloride tubing , and the sampling flow rate was set to 2.0 L/min
Text: This flow rate was checked at the beginning and end of sampling and , when possible , at regular periods between these times
Text: The sampler was worn for a full work shift to ensure that the measured concentrations represented daily average exposures
Text: We anticipated that some workers might consider personal sampling an unacceptable intrusion , in which cases the sampler could be placed at a fixed location within the normal working environment
Text: This was not necessary , however , and we were able to monitor all tasks in the conventional manner .
Text: In railway transport , it was not possible to directly observe the work practices of the train drivers owing to the distances involved and limited space available on board
Text: Sampling was restricted to short-haul locomotive driver - that is , drivers of shunting locomotives and those operating suburban goods trains in a circular route around the city
Text: At the end of sampling , the filter cassette was removed from the sampling head and the size-selective foam insert was removed and discarded
Text: The cassettes were then analyzed gravimetrically to determine the respirable dust concentrations
Text: Each filter sample was analyzed for organic carbon ( OC ) and EC using evolved gas analysis with a thermal optical sensor in accordance with National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health ( NIOSH ) method 5040 ( NIOSH 1996 )
Text: This work was carried out by David Dabill of the Health and Safety Laboratory , Sheffield , England
Text: After analysis of the filter samples , the respirable dust concentrations and EC concentrations were calculated
Text: The geometric mean ( GM ) and geometric standard deviation ( GSD ) of concentrations were calculated for each set of measurements from similarly exposed groups .
Text: Airborne concentrations of EC are taken to be a reliable marker of diesel exhaust concentrations , and Verma and colleagues ( 1999 ) have shown this to be a suitable method for monitoring diesel exhaust exposures in the railroad industry
Text: The American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists ( ACGIH ) has now proposed a threshold limit value of 0.05 mg/m3 for diesel exhaust ( ACGIH 2000 ) , and until further clarification , this value is assumed to apply to the EC content of submicron dust particles.Use of the respirable dust samplers was not practical in the oil-shale mine , so cyclone-type respirable dust samplers ( SIMPEDS samplers , Casella , London , UK ) were used instead
Text: These samplers were prepared for gravimetric determination , but losses from the filter media due to the brittle nature of the quartz fiber filters prevented it
Text: The samples were analyzed for EC and OC , however , as described previously in this report
Text: Ideally , we would have preferred to use a sampler incorporating a preselector with a submicron-sized cutoff for the oil-shale mine , but this type of equipment was not available at the time of survey
Text: The measurements were therefore intended to be indicative only
Text: RESULTS
Text: FEASIBILITY OF EPIDEMIOLGIC STUDY
Text: Operational field trials were conducted by introducing the low emission test fuel into a small underground lead/zinc mine that traditionally used high sulfur imported fuel
Text: A 40 to 50 percent reduction in DP measurements was found in the general work areas and return airways in this mine , which was similar to the results predicted in the above-ground tunnel tests
Text: Trials conducted at Tower Colliery , where commercial diesel fuel that complied with the coal mines regulations was substituted with the experimental fuel , resulted in reductions in DP exposure to the work force of around 10 to 15percent , which is slightly lower than the 25 percent reduction predicted by the tunnel tests
Text: In both mines the work force commented favorably on the use of the low emission fuels , reporting an immediate reduction in irritation and an improvement in the aroma of the emissions
Text: The low emission test fuel has now been incorporated into all BHP underground coal mines in NSW
Text: In designing a fuel specification to meet low emission standards , other parameters in addition to sulphur have to be considered , such as cetane number ( which affects cold start , emissions , and diesel knock ) , density ( which affects power and hence emission levels ) , cloud point ( which creates problems in cold climates ) , flash point ( which indicates flammability ) , and distillation range ( which indicates higher ends that result in the creation of additional DP ) .
Text: Scrubber Tank and Air Filter Cleanliness
Text: A series of tunnel runs were conducted separately on two machines to determine the extent of operator exposure to DP consistent with both normal and abnormal maintenance procedures
Text: The raw exhaust scrubber tank was trialed dry , wet , and after extensive cleaning using chemical agents and a high pressure water jet
Text: The NSW legislative requirements are that this trap be filled with water so as to act as a flame trap
Text: Water in the scrubber tank resulted in a 20 to 30 percent reduction in DP exposures
Text: However , the additional degree of cleaning instigated in the tests did not increase efficiency of capture above that of normal flushing procedures
Text: It was concluded that the cleanliness of the internal surfaces of water-filled scrubber tanks is not a major factor in reducing diesel aerosol particulate from engines
Text: It is more likely that the presence of an impaction barrier such as water is the major influence in achieving the levels of reductions observed with vehicles fitted with scrubber tanks , compared with those without .
Text: Testing using a series of new and very dirty air intake filters failed to find any significant effect on DP exposures
Text: This suggests that intake air filters would need to be in an extremely poor condition before any deterioration in DP levels may occur .
Text: Engine Chemical Decoking
Text: Mechanical decoking of engines has long been known to have a beneficial effect on engine performance , and the emergence of chemical decoking systems has the potential for similar benefits
Text: Short-term tests previously conducted at Tower Colliery have shown a significant reduction in the generation of DP after chemical decoking
Text: Further tests were conducted to determine the long-term effectiveness of procedures for the chemical decoking of engines and to evaluate the effects on component wear
Text: Sufficient baseline DP data were obtained in the underground tunnel on a Noyes MPV , which was then removed to the underground workshop and chemically decoked
Text: After decoking , the vehicle was returned to the test station and retested over a number of successive days until the DP indicated a downward trend
Text: The vehicle was returned to the vehicle fleet to resume normal duties , from which it was extracted at regular intervals over a 9-month period for retesting
Text: A significant downward trend of DP levels was obtained soon after treatment and maintained over the 9-month period of sampling ( Figure 3 )
Text: Apart from routine maintenance , no other work has been performed on the engine over the sampling period and no adverse mechanical effects were noted up to the present , which is 18 months after treatment .
Text: A second Noyes MPV was decoked some 3 months after the first vehicle
Text: Decreased DP emissions were also found , although the amount of reduction was less due to the better condition of the engine prior to the deco-king
Text: During the decoking process and for a number of hours thereafter , extensive quantities of soot were observed in the vehicle exhaust and water-filled scrubber tank
Text: This release of built-up carbon requires the careful management of exhaust emissions to ensure that workers are not inadvertently exposed to a range of noxious products .
Text: Disposable Exhaust Filter
Text: Considerable work has been undertaken by the U.S.Bureau of Mines , Donaldson Inc. , and Jeffrey Inc
Text: to develop a disposable exhaust filter system
Text: These filter types have a proven record in reducing DP exposures in underground vehicles , but unfortunately they have contributed to several unacceptable situations under operational conditions in U.S.mines where hot exhaust has carbonized and even ignited the paper filters
Text: A polypropylene filter material was obtained which had enhanced flame-resistant characteristics and good filtration characteristics , was not adversely affected by water mist , and was obtainable at reasonable cost .
Text: A mobile generator ( P
Text: J
Text: Berriman Pty Ltd Power Tram ) fitted with and without filters to the scrubber tank exhaust was tested under full power load in the underground test tunnel for durations of up to four shifts
Text: A pressure gauge was placed between the exhaust manifold and the filter to measure changes in back pressure that are known to affect engine performance and exhaust emission levels
Text: Significant reductions in diesel aerosol particulates were recorded using the filter for periods in excess of three consecutive shifts ( Figure 4 ) , and even though back pressure increased to 20 kPa , no effect was detected on engine performance
Text: Without the filter visibility in the heading was poor , with significant levels of water vapor and soot present , while with the filter visibility was improved significantly .
Text: A prototype filter unit was also fitted to a front end loader vehicle ( Eimco 913 )
Text: Similar reductions in DP levels were achieved
Text: however , only a maximum two shifts’ duration was obtained from the filters as the poorer engine condition generated very high DP levels ( nonfilter , 1.2 mg/m3 operator exposure ) .
Text: Such exhaust filter devices provide the best short-term means of controlling DP from low use , heavy haulage vehicles in the underground coal mining industry
Text: It is necessary that appropriate safety systems be installed with the unit to ensure that the filters are never exposed to temperatures above their design characteristics and that they are changed out on a regular basis ( e.g. , after each 24 hours of use ) .
Text: Mine Ventilation
Text: Considerable emphasis is placed on ventilation as a viable means of controlling diesel exhaust emissions in underground coal mines by regulatory authorities
Text: A series of tests were conducted with a mobile generator ( PJB Power Tram ) and a transport vehicle ( Noyes MPV ) over a range of ventilation rates of 5 to 15 and 5 to 10 m3/s , respectively
Text: In addition , tests were carried out when both machines were in combined operations in the same heading with flow rates of 5 to 15 m3/s .
Text: A linear decrease in operator DP levels was found for increased air flow when machines were operating alone
Text: When machines were used in combination , the actual results were different from the calculated additive values , being less in the low flow conditions and higher in the air flows greater than 12 m3/s ( Figure 5 )
Text: Subsequent ventilation testing indicated that velocity pressure was not a significant factor in affecting engine performance or emission levels and that thermal stratification in the tunnel was observed only at flow rates of less than 6 m3/s
Text: The reason for the difference in additive effects of multiple machinery remains unclear
Text: At some flow rates thermal stratification may result in higher exposures to some members of the work force .
Text: RESULTS
Text: Of the 293 workers participating in the exposure study , 75–78 % ( depending on exposure agent ) was monitored on more than one occasion for the same agent
Text: The GM exposure for total dust , respirable dust , fibers , and SiC for all workers was 1.6 mg m−3 , 0.30 mg m−3 , 0.033 fibers cm−3 , and 0.069 mg m−3 , respectively ( Tables 2 and 3 )
Text: The GM exposure for quartz and cristobalite in the furnace department was 2.2 and 3.7 µg m−3 , respectively ( Table 3 )
Text: The crystalline silica exposures for workers in the processing and maintenance departments were generally low
Text: More than 90 % of the cristobalite samples from each of these departments were below the LOD , whereas the corresponding proportions for quartz exposure levels were 65 and 58 % , respectively
Text: Respirators were used by 74 % of the workers some or all of the time ( Føreland et al. , 2008 )
Text: The actual exposure levels were therefore lower than indicated by the measurements .
Text: Determinants of exposure for all measurements
Text: Plant as a determinant of dusts exposure explained only 0.33–4.4 % of the BW variance
Text: Department was a major predictor of fiber and SiC exposure , explaining 70 and 38 % of the BW variance , respectively , whereas the BW variances for total dust and respirable dust were reduced only by less than 10 %
Text: The furnace department was associated with higher exposure to fibers and lower exposure to SiC
Text: The processing department was associated with higher exposure to total dust , respirable dust , and SiC , and lower exposure to fibers
Text: Job group was a major predictor of exposure for all agents explaining 43 % ( total dust ) , 44 % ( respirable dust ) , 82 % ( fiber ) , and 78 % ( SiC ) of the BW variance
Text: Combining plant and job group in the model gave the best fit for all agents explaining 45 % ( total dust ) , 48 % ( respirable dust ) , 82 % ( fiber ) , and 79 % ( SiC ) of the BW variance
Text: The explained WW variance was 0.5 % or less for all the models .
Text: Determinants of exposure at department level
Text: Job group was the most important determinant of exposure for all agents in the furnace and processing departments
Text: The final models for the furnace and processing departments are presented in Tables 4 and 5 , respectively
Text: The only department-specific determinant in the furnace and processing departments that was a significant predictor of exposure in the final models was process disturbances , i.e
Text: unwanted events leading to a stop or delay in the production process .
Text: The shift schedules could differ between plants and job groups
Text: Workers within some job groups worked only daytime ( e.g
Text: all job groups in the maintenance department ) , while other worked two , three , or five shift schedules
Text: The effect of shift was seen most clearly in the furnace department where working night shift was a determinant of lower exposure to most agents
Text: The same effect was seen for total dust in the processing department
Text: Job group was a less important predictor of exposure in the maintenance department compared to other departments and was only retained in the final models for total dust , respirable dust , and fiber ( Table 6 )
Text: The models explained 14–89 % of the BW variance and 0–11 % of the WW variance .
Text: Determinants of exposure at job group level
Text: Several tasks were identified as predictors of exposure
Text: Assisting with assembling and filling of the furnaces had a geometric mean ratio ( GMR ) of 3.3–8.0 , meaning a 3.3–8.0-fold increased exposure for the charger and mix operator
Text: Manually sorting and having the sorting area inside the furnace hall was associated with a 1.5–6.7-fold increased exposure for the sorter operator
Text: Cleaning lead to a 1.3–6.2-fold increase in exposure for operators in the furnace department , but a decreased exposure for other refinery workers
Text: Filling of pallet boxes with SiC resulted in a 1.6–2.7-fold increased exposure for operators in the refinery and changing of pallet boxes resulted in 1.5–2.4-fold increased exposure for fines operators
Text: Maintenance in the furnace hall resulted in a 3.9–4.8-fold increase in fiber exposure , and maintenance in the processing department resulted in a 1.7–2.1-fold increase in exposure to SiC
Text: Work in control rooms , laboratories , fresh air ventilated crane cabins , offices and maintenance outside the furnace hall , and processing department were predictors of decreased dusts exposure with a GMR of 0.14–0.74
Text: The final models for determinants on job group level are presented in Table 7 ( furnace department ) , Table 8 ( processing department ) , and Table 9 ( maintenance department ) .
Text: Evaluation of a Disposable Diesel Exhaust Filter for Permissible Mining Machines
Text: ABSTRACT
Text: The U.S
Text: Bureau of Mines ( USBM ) Diesel Research Program emphasizes the development and evaluation of emission control devices to reduce exposure of miners to diesel exhaust pollutants
Text: Studies by the USBM have shown that diesel exhaust aerosol ( DBA ) contributes a substantial portion of the respirable aerosol in underground coal mines using diesel equipment not equipped , with emission controls .
Text: The USBM and the Donaldson Co. , Inc. , Minneapolis , MN , have developed a low-temperature , disposable diesel exhaust filter ( DDEF ) for use on , permissible diesel haulage vehicles equipped with waterbath exhaust conditioners
Text: These were evaluated in three underground mines to determine their effectiveness in reducing DEA concentrations
Text: The DDEF reduced DEA concentrations from 70 to 90 pct at these mines
Text: The usable life of the filter ranged from 10 to 32 h , depending on factors that affect DEA output , such as mine altitude , engine type , and duty-cycle
Text: Cost per filter is approximately $ 40 .
Text: FIELD EVALUATION OF DISPOSABLE DIESEL EXHAUST FILTER
Text: The collection efficiency and life expectancy of the DDEF system were evaluated during week-long field studies at three mines .
Text: Aerosol data were collected in continuous miner sections of these underground coal mines while the diesel haulage vehicles were equipped with and without the DDEF installed
Text: These mines are designated M , R , and S
Text: Mine M was located in Utah at an altitude of approximately 2,400 m ( 8,000 ft )
Text: Mine R was located in Alabama and mine S in Kentucky
Text: Each mine produces high volatile , bituminous coal with shift production levels varying from 272 to 604 kg/shift
Text: Seam heights varied from 1.5 to 2.4 m
Text: Mines M and R use continuous mining to develop longwall panels
Text: Mine S is a room-and-pillar operation that uses a continuous miner .
Text: Mines R and S operated three to four Jeffrey 4110 Ramcars in the test section
Text: The Jeffrey 4110 Ramcars were equipped with Motorenwerke Mannheim ( MWM ) D916-6 engines , rated at 74.6 kW ( 100 hp )
Text: Mine Mused three to four Jeffrey 4114 Ramcars powered by Caterpillar 3306 PCNA engines
Text: These engines were derated for high altitude operation from 111.9 to 82.1 kW ( 150 to 110 hp ) .
Text: At the first mine , the Ramcars were operated for 4 days with the DDEF installed and for 1 day without the DDEF installed
Text: At the other two mines , the Ramcars were operated for 3 days with the DDEF and for 2 days without
Text: SAMPLING AND ANALYSIS METHODS
Text: It was shown in the laboratory , and in underground mines , that inertial impaction , followed by gravi­metric analysis , can be used to separate and sample DEA and mineral dust aerosol fractions , and provide estimates of DEA concentrations
Text: Two types of personal diesel exhaust aerosol samplers ( PDEAS ) were developed to achieve this result and are depicted in figure 4 .
Text: Both have three stages and employ inertial impaction to separate diesel and mineral dust fractions of the sampled respirable aerosol
Text: The first stage is an inertial pre­ classifier , a 10-mm-Dorr-Oliver cyclone that separates and removes the larger , nonrespirable aerosol
Text: The second stage is a four-nozzle impactor with a sharp 50 pct cut point of 0.8 ) .Lm aerodynamic diameter
Text: Most aerosol particles larger than 0.8 ) .Lm , the respirable coal dust , are deposited on an impaction substrate in this stage .
Text: The third stage is a filter which collects the remaining aerosol of less than 0.8 ) .Lm aerodynamic diameter , the DEA
Text: Both samplers operate at a flow rate of 2 L/min , which is compatible with both personal sampler pumps and the Dorr-Oliver cyclone .
Text: Preliminary evaluations of the sampling technique indi­cate that these are accurate to within 25 pct , 95 pct of the time , for concentration levels above the estimated limit of detection of 0.3 mg/m3
Text: Below this level , indications are that the 95 pct confidence interval can exceed 60 pct due to interferences caused by submicron mineral dust and background atmospheric aerosol .
Text: Both types of PDEAS were used to evaluate the filtra­tion efficiency of the DDEF
Text: Figure 5 shows the sampling stations used in the three entry longwall development sec­ ions of one of the mines in which the evaluation tests were performed
Text: Up to 35 PDEAS samples were collect­ ed during each normal production shift in the ventilation intake entry ( I ) , haulageway entry ( H ) , on the diesel shut­tle cars ( SC ) , in the return air entry ( R ) and , in a few instances , individuals
Text: Ventilation in the section is indi­cated by arrows .
Text: In addition to the PDEAS samples , aerosol size dis­tribution samples were collected in mines M and S using a lO-stage micro-orifice , uniform deposit impactor ( MOUDI )
Text: The analyses of MOUDI-derived size dis­tributions provided accurate concentrations of DEA and respirable coal mine dust aerosol and were also used to evaluate the performance of the PDEAS .
Text: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Text: Table 1 summarizes the PDEAS results of aerosol measurements taken with and without filters installed
Text: The table also indicates the reduction of DEA in the mine environment .
Text: DEA concentrations with the DDEF installed were less than or equal to 0.3 mg/m3 at all locations
Text: The concen­trations and standard deviations shown in table 1 are av­erage values uncorrected for intake air concentration or production and ventilation changes
Text: However , the DEA reductions shown in the table were calculated by including correction factors for these parameters
Text: The equation used to calculate the percent reductions , 6 , is 6 =100 [ 1- C ~/o ]
Text: w Here , Cw and Cw/ o are the intake corrected average DEA concentrations measured with and without the DDEF in place
Text: corrected for ventilation , section production , and aerosol background concentration in the intake air .
Text: They are calculated using
Text: Here , C is the intake corrected average concentration , Cm is the average measured concentration for day n , 5m is the correction factor for the measured concentration , and CIS I is the average aerosol concentration measured in the section intake and its correction factor , respectively
Text: The correction factors are determined from production tonnage and measured ventilation rates by
Text: Here , P and Pm are the average production tonnage for the days during which the measured condition pertains , i.e. , with or without filter , and the production tonnage for the shift of the measured concentration Cm
Text: Similarly , V and Vx are the average ventilation rate for the shift during which the measured condition pertains and the ventilation rate at the location and on the day for the measured con­centration Cx
Text: The production correction only applies to the concentrations measured on the section .
Text: Also , since daily measured concentrations are not given in the table , a net correction factor is determined from the average measured and corrected values for the diesel aerosol con­centrations and is reported in the table as an indication of the size of the corrections made
Text: These analyses indicate that the DDEF reduced DEA concentrations in the mine atmosphere by 95 pct with a standard deviation of 6 pet at mine M , 72 pct with a stand­ard deviation of 4.5 pct at mine R , and 87 pct with a standard deviation of 4 pct at mine S .
Text: Figures 6 and 7 show the size distribution of mine aerosol for mines M and S with and without the DDEF
Text: These figures are based on data collected from the MOUDIs located at the haulage site
Text: They effectively il­lustrate two points
Text: ( 1 ) The DDEF is effective at remov­ing most of the submicron aerosol from the mine atmos­phere and ( 2 ) most submicron aerosol is attributable to diesel exhaust .
Text: FACTORS AFFECTING FILTER LIFE
Text: The useful service life of a DDEF is determined by the engine manufacturer 's allowable exhaust backpressure lim­it
Text: The maximum backpressure specified for the Caterpil­lar 3306 engine is 86 cm ( 34 in ) of water
Text: For the MWM 916-6 engine the maximum specified backpressure is 102 cm ( 40 in ) of water
Text: The exhaust backpressure is de­termined by summing the pressure drops across the water­ bath scrubber , exhaust piping , and the filter
Text: Measure­ments on DDEF systems , which were used during this testing , showed that the maximum backpressure imposed by the waterbath scrubber and exhaust system was ap­proximately 25 cm ( 10 in ) of water , so when the pressure drop across the filter reached 61 cm ( 24 in ) of water , for the CAT 3306 , or 76 cm ( 30 in ) of water for the MWM 916-6 , the filter required replacement .
Text: The major factor affecting filter life on a waterbath scrubber equipped vehicle is the amount of DEA gener­ated by the engine , which is dependent on such factors as the vehicle 's duty cycle , engine type and condition , and mine altitude
Text: During the field evaluations , the ODEF lasted up to 10 h on the Jeffrey 4114 Ramcar , and up to 32 h on the 4110 Ramcar .
Text: Another consideration affecting filter life is water saturation
Text: Owing to space limitations , the water trap was not sized to handle the excessive amount of water expelled from an overfilled waterbath scrubber upon starting the engine
Text: Thus , a significant amount of water may pass into the filter canister , saturating the filter when the system is overfilled
Text: The simplest solutions to this problem are to avoid overfilling waterbath scrubber , or to postpone install­ ing the filter until after waterbath scrubber maintenance and initial engine startup .
Text: SAFETY CONCERNS
Text: Jeffrey received MSHA approval to use the retrofit DDEF system on both the 4110 and 4114 Ramcars
Text: Mine operators have reported some problems with vehicles equipped with DDEF systems
Text: Under certain circum­stances , the exhaust temperature will significantly exceed the recommended 95° C maximum for the filter
Text: This condition results when the waterbath safety shutdown sys­tem malfunctions or is bypassed
Text: The excessive tempera­ture may cause ignition of the filter and collected die­sel particulate
Text: To avoid this problem , it is important to maintain the vehicle 's safety systems in a permissible condition .
Text: Direct contact with used DDEFs should be avoided if possible
Text: Gloves should be worn during installation and removal to avoid contact with surfaces coated with soot and grease
Text: The DDEFs should be bagged and brought to a disposal facility .
Text: Personal Exposure to Dust , Endotoxin and Crystalline Silica in California Agriculture
Text: ABSTRACT
Text: Aims : The aim of this study was to measure personal exposure to dust , endotoxin and crystalline silica during various agricultural operations in California over a period of one year .
Text: Methods : Ten farms were randomly selected in Yolo and Solano counties and workers were invited to wear personal sampling equipment to measure inhalable and respirable dust levels during various operations
Text: The samples were analysed for endotoxin using the Limulus Amebocyte Lysate assay and crystalline silica content using X-ray diffraction
Text: In total 142 inhalable samples and 144 respirable samples were collected .
Text: Results : The measurements showed considerable difference in exposure levels between various operations , in particular for the inhalable fraction of the dust and the endotoxin
Text: Machine harvesting of tree crops ( Geometric mean ( GM ) = 45.1 mg/m3 ) and vegetables ( GM = 7.9 mg/m3 ) , and cleaning of poultry houses ( GM = 6.7 mg/m3 ) showed the highest inhalable dust levels
Text: Cleaning of poultry houses also showed the highest inhalable endotoxin levels ( GM = 1861 EU/m3 )
Text: Respirable dust levels were generally low , except for machine harvesting of tree crops ( GM = 2.8 mg/m3 ) and vegetables ( GM = 0.9 mg/m3 )
Text: Respirable endotoxin levels were also low
Text: For the inhalable dust fraction , levels were reduced considerably when an enclosed cabin was present
Text: The percentage of crystalline silica was overall higher in the respirable dust samples than the inhalable dust samples .
Text: Conclusions : Considerable differences exist in personal exposure levels to dust , endotoxin and crystalline silica during various agricultural operations in California agriculture with some operations showing very high levels .
Text: MATERIAL AND METHODS
Text: Dust sampling
Text: Seventeen farms in Solano and Yolo counties , situated in the Central Valley near the capital Sacramento of the State of California , US were randomly selected , stratified for commodities , from our farm operator cohort which is described elsewhere ( Nieuwenhuijsen et al. , 1996 ) , and ten farms agreed to participate ( Table 1 )
Text: The farms were visited 8 times with periodic intervals over the period April 1995–June 1996 , except for farms 1 , 6 , 8 and 10 which were visited 5 , 7 , 3 and 9 times respectively
Text: Farm 8 went out of business during the study
Text: Workers on the farms were asked to wear a personal sampler during various operations on the farms
Text: This was either 1 ) an IOM inhalable dust sampler ( SKC West , Fullerton , CA ) , containing a 25 mm diameter polyvinylchloride ( PVC ) filter ( pore size 5 μm ) and connected to a personal sampling pump which run at 2 litres/minute to measure the inhalable dust fraction
Text: or 2 ) a personal respirable dust cyclone ( BGI Inc , Waltham , MA ) , containing a 37 mm diameter PVC filter ( pore size 5 μm ) , connected to a personal sampling pump run at 2.2 litres/minute ( 50 % cut point diameter = 4 μm ) to measure the respirable fraction
Text: The filters were weighed before and after sampling on an six figure ATI Cahn C-35 microbalance ( ATI Orion Cahn , Boston , MA ) , and a dust concentration calculated using the difference in filter weight , after adjustment for blanks , and sampling volume
Text: The results were expressed as mg/m3
Text: For the IOM inhalable dust sampler the detection limit was 0.030 mg per filter and for the cyclone the detection limit was 0.067 mg .
Text: Endotoxin analysis
Text: To measure the endotoxin concentration on the filters , dust was extracted individually in 10 ml of sterile , non pyrogenic water ( LAL reagent water
Text: BioWhittaker ) in a 50 ml centrifuge tube by rocking at room temperature for 60 minutes ( Labquake shaker
Text: Labindustries , Berkeley , CA )
Text: The extracts were then centrifuged at 1000 g for 10 minutes , and dilutions of 1 ml of the supernatant fluids were analyzed in duplicate for endotoxins by the kinetic chromogenic modification of the Limulus Amebocyte Lysate ( LAL ) assay ( Kinetic-QCL kit lot numbers 4L3010 , 5L2180 , 5L3560 , 6L0440
Text: Pyrogen-Free water lot numbers 4L2870 , 5L1160 , 5L3470 , 5L4720
Text: Kinetic-QCL reagent lot numbers 4L1760 , 5L1780 , 5L3030 , 5L473G
Text: Certified Standard Endotoxin 4L1370 , 4L5090 , 5L2110 , standards were standardized to the common standard endotoxin , EC-5 ) ( Kinetic-QCL
Text: BioWhittaker )
Text: If the supernatant fluids could not be analyzed immediately , then they were frozen at −80°C
Text: The procedure described in the commercial endotoxin kit is followed , and inhibition/enhancement assays were used as required
Text: Results were reported in terms of Endotoxin Units ( EU ) per cubic meter of air
Text: The limit of detection was 0.05 EU/ml .
Text: Silica analysis
Text: X-ray diffraction was used to measure the crystalline silica content of the dust
Text: To get enough dust for analysis , samples , including the filters , with the same job codes were pooled and then they were placed in 50 ml centrifuge tubes for shipment from Davis to the analysis laboratory in Morgantown
Text: Only pooled samples with more than 1 measurement , a combined sampling volume over 1000 litres or more , and a combined weight of 0.2 mg or more were used for analysis
Text: The filters with water were dried in their containers and tetrahydrofuran ( THF ) was added to dissolve the filters
Text: After dissolving the filters they were sonicated for 20 minutes and filtered onto tared silver membrane ( FWS-B ) filters
Text: The dried silver membrane filters were then dried to determine the total particulate weight for each sample
Text: Samples with greater than 3 mg particulate weight were dissolved again in THF , divided and filtered onto silver membrane filters to maintain a particle load of less than 3 mg .
Text: The silver filters were analyzed for quartz and cristobalite using the NIOSH 7500-NMAM method ( NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods , Fourth Edition , 1994 )
Text: Standards and samples were run concurrently and an external calibration curve was prepared from the integrated intensities rather than using the suggested normalization procedure
Text: Using this technique the limits of detection for quartz and cristobalite were 0.01 mg and 0.02 mg respectively
Text: The results were expressed as percentage crystalline silica in the dust .
Text: Silica analysis
Text: X-ray diffraction was used to measure the crystalline silica content of the dust
Text: To get enough dust for analysis , samples , including the filters , with the same job codes were pooled and then they were placed in 50 ml centrifuge tubes for shipment from Davis to the analysis laboratory in Morgantown
Text: Only pooled samples with more than 1 measurement , a combined sampling volume over 1000 litres or more , and a combined weight of 0.2 mg or more were used for analysis
Text: The filters with water were dried in their containers and tetrahydrofuran ( THF ) was added to dissolve the filters
Text: After dissolving the filters they were sonicated for 20 minutes and filtered onto tared silver membrane ( FWS-B ) filters
Text: The dried silver membrane filters were then dried to determine the total particulate weight for each sample
Text: Samples with greater than 3 mg particulate weight were dissolved again in THF , divided and filtered onto silver membrane filters to maintain a particle load of less than 3 mg .
Text: The silver filters were analyzed for quartz and cristobalite using the NIOSH 7500-NMAM method ( NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods , Fourth Edition , 1994 )
Text: Standards and samples were run concurrently and an external calibration curve was prepared from the integrated intensities rather than using the suggested normalization procedure
Text: Using this technique the limits of detection for quartz and cristobalite were 0.01 mg and 0.02 mg respectively
Text: The results were expressed as percentage crystalline silica in the dust .
Text: RESULTS
Text: Inhalable dust levels
Text: The measurements showed considerable differences in personal exposure levels between various operations ( Tables 2-5 )
Text: The highest inhalable dust levels were measured for machine harvesting of both tree crops ( nuts ) and vegetables , and scraping poultry houses ( Table 2 )
Text: Lower but still considerable levels were measured for ground preparation operations , mechanical mowing of weeds and feeding poultry
Text: Inhalable dust levels were lower during ground preparation and machine harvesting of dry harvested field crops when an enclosed cabin was present
Text: An analysis of variance showed that operation alone explained 28 % of the variation in inhalable dust exposure and that operation , the type of commodity and the presence of enclosed cabin together explained 60 % of the variation in inhalable dust exposure .
Text: Inhalable endotoxin levels
Text: The highest average inhalable endotoxin levels were measured during cleaning of poultry houses ( Table 3 )
Text: Livestock related operations in general showed higher inhalable endotoxin levels than field crop , vegetable and fruit and nut related operations , although relatively high inhalable endotoxin levels were measured during machine harvesting of vegetables ( tomatoes ) and nuts , and mowing of weeds .
Text: Respirable dust levels
Text: Respirable dust levels were generally low , with the highest levels being measured for machine harvesting of tree crops ( nuts ) and vegetables ( Table 4 )
Text: A large percentage of the respirable measurements were below the limit of detection and the presented geometric means and geometric standard deviations should therefore be interpreted with caution
Text: The respirable dust level during ground preparation was slightly lower when an enclosed cabin was present
Text: An analyses of variance showed that operation alone explained 19 % of the variation in inhalable dust exposure and that operation , the type of commodity and the presence of enclosed cabin together explained 41 % of the variation in inhalable dust exposure .
Text: Respirable endotoxin levels
Text: The respirable endotoxin levels were generally low , and a large proportion were under the limit of detection ( Table 5 )
Text: The highest respirable endotoxin levels were measured during the machine harvest of vegetables ( tomatoes ) .
Text: Crystalline silica
Text: The percentage of crystalline silica in the dust varied between operation and between the dust fractions ( Table 6 )
Text: Overall , the respirable dust fraction showed a higher percentage of crystalline silica in the dust than the inhalable dust fraction .
Text: Model for Terminal Dock and Shop Operations
Text: The general model can be modified as shown below to reflect the specific sources of emissions experienced by dock and shop workers :
Text: Exposure Intensity ( EC µg/m3 ) = 0 + 1 ( Background ) + 2 ( Indoor Emissions in Terminal Dock or Shop ) + 3 ( Yard Emissions )
Text: The background for a terminal is the local air pollution in its location : city versus small town or rural area
Text: The AIRS data can be used to estimate the background levels
Text: Outside cities , the terminals in rural areas and small towns are expected to have background air pollution levels consistent with rural measurements
Text: Comparison between measured background levels and local air pollution data can determine how well the available pollution data correlate with measurements of terminal-area background exposures .
Text: Indoor emissions in the dock area are defined by the number of forklifts within the dock area
Text: The forklift emissions are released into the volume of air in the terminal , which is proportional to the floor space or the number of doors
Text: This factor can be examined as a function of company data on each terminal’s loading dock area , number of loading dock doors , and number of forklifts assigned
Text: Historically , diesel forklifts were used in larger terminals in 3 of the 4 companies ( see Table 2 )
Text: Therefore , for the reconstruction of historical exposure , a scaling factor based on data from Zaebst et al ( 1991 ) can be developed to account for this exposure for the years diesel forklifts were used .
Text: Indoor emissions in shop are defined by number and type of tractors or trucks being repaired
Text: The emissions are released into the air volume of the shop so the size affects the exposure intensity
Text: The size of the shop can be obtained from company records , and the number of vehicles can be estimated from the number of mechanics assigned to that location
Text: These factors can be examined in the exposure assessment as potential predictors of exposures .
Text: The quantity of outdoor yard emissions entering the building is affected by the number and type of vehicles operating in the yard and by the amount of dilution or mixing in the yard before the emissions enter the terminal or the shop
Text: The average number of diesel vehicles and terminal size can be examined as predictors of exposure at each location .
Text: For P & D/dockworkers who may work on a loading dock or drive a P & D truck depending on terminal size and location , exposure assessment would require weighting time spent on the dock versus time driving
Text: This proportion would be applied to the exposure model developed for each separate work location
Text: Company payroll records can be used to identify hours spent working on a loading dock or driving a truck and to determine an exposure profile ( mean and variation ) based on terminal size and location for a typical P & D/dockworker .
Text: Estimation of Historical Exposures
Text: Two definitions of long-term exposure to diesel exhaust can be assigned to each individual
Text: First , exposure can be defined categorically on the basis of yearly job title , terminal size , and terminal location ( that is , region of the country and urban versus rural area )
Text: Second , exposure can be defined quantitatively as cumulative dose of EC using the statistical model derived from the exposure assessment discussed in the previous section
Text: The company personnel files provide chronological job title and terminal information
Text: Teamsters union pension fund records of contributions made by each unionized trucking company on behalf of a worker supplement this information for retired workers .
Text: Previous epidemiologic studies have used job title alone to categorize exposure to diesel exhaust ( Steenland et al 1990
Text: Cohen and Higgins 1995
Text: Bhatia et al 1998 )
Text: For this cohort , the results showed that job alone might give highly misclassified exposure assignments
Text: This definition should be refined by including terminal characteristics and formulating job-terminal exposure categories for historical periods
Text: The different duties encompassed by the job title determine the potential contact that an individual has with diesel vehicles
Text: However , size and location of the trucking terminal also appear to strongly influence exposure and the actual definition of job duties covered by the job title
Text: Large terminals have greater activity and number of vehicles , which leads to higher exposures
Text: At smaller terminals there is also less distinction between dockworkers and P & D drivers because a given worker often per- forms both sets of duties
Text: Therefore , a dockworker at a small terminal does not have the same exposures as one at a larger terminal
Text: In addition , the urban or rural location of the terminal influences the exposures experienced by all employees , including the drivers
Text: Terminals in urban areas have higher levels of background air pollution owing to the other sources around them
Text: Drivers based at these terminals are more likely to drive congested city routes than drivers from rural terminals
Text: Long-haul drivers are assigned to a home terminal , indicating the region of the country in which they are most likely to drive
Text: Intercity highways and those in the heavily populated East Coast and West Coast areas are more congested than those in less populated parts of the country
Text: All of these factors influence exposure to diesel exhaust and therefore should be taken into account when grouping trucking employees into exposure categories
Text: Dockworkers and clerks at small rural terminals appeared to have the lowest exposure , with exposures at or near background levels .
Text: Several semiquantitative exposure indices can be developed from the duration an individual has worked in the above exposure categories
Text: These permit evaluation of important exposure contrasts
Text: Because there is little cross- over among the categories , risk associated with years of work at small terminals can be compared with risk associated with years of work in large terminals to determine whether the cumulative risk differs by terminal size
Text: SinceP & D trucks are assigned to specific terminals and terminals vary in the year when they first used diesel trucks , years driving a diesel P & D truck can be used to index driver exposure
Text: Similarly , diesel exposure for mechanics and dockworkers can be calculated on the basis of an individual’s assignment to a specific terminal
Text: Years of use of diesel-powered forklifts can also be determined
Text: Years of driving a P & D truck for city delivery can be compared with years of rural delivery to determine whether driving in traffic increases the risk beyond driving by itself
Text: These categorical and semiquantitative exposure categories have a major advantage in their historical accuracy of potential exposure because they are based on company records and do not depend on the accuracy or precision of retrospective exposure estimates .
Text: Quantitative historical exposures can be backward extrapolated from a statistical evaluation of current exposures
Text: The same statistical model can be used based on historical changes in the exposure factors
Text: In developing this approach , important elements are ( 1 ) a set of factors for which historical data are available over the whole time period of interest , and ( 2 ) data that document the qualitative and quantitative effects of changes that can be used for model validation
Text: Our feasibility study demonstrated that this is generally possible , but all historical factors that might be used to extrapolate exposure in the models developed may not be available
Text: For example , air pollution data for the 1970s are limited , and specific highway and regional traffic count data are not generally available before the 1970s
Text: The effect of these incomplete data on the extrapolation of historical exposure will depend on the importance of the individual factors in the exposure model
Text: Possibly surrogates for these incomplete data can be determined
Text: However , these limitations would affect calculation of only a small fraction of cumulative exposure if diesel exposure were to be assessed through 2000 and beyond in the design of a cohort study .
Text: Other exposure-modifying factors can not be modeled explicitly but may be important in evaluating the measurement data and extrapolating past exposures
Text: For example , local variations in the mix of vehicles and traffic patterns will affect the exposure relationship
Text: Cities and urban areas can have substantial variation in local industries and geography
Text: The effects of these limitations can be mini- mized with a sufficiently large statistical sample that cuts across the whole industry
Text: Such a sample would permit reasonably precise historical estimates of average exposure intensity within categories .
Text: In the ideal case , we would want extensive measurement data to validate our extrapolation model
Text: However , occupational and environmental measurements of EC are limited , especially data collected with the best methods , and are not available prior to the mid 1980s
Text: Several studies have shown that reflectance from deposits on filter paper and the old method for measuring air pollu- tion by light transmission through deposits on filter paper ( coefficient of haze ) are highly correlated with EC measurements ( Cass et al 1984
Text: Kinney et al 2000 )
Text: As a result , it may be possible to obtain estimates of EC for comparison with our model in the large cities where coefficient of haze was routinely measured .
Text: Changes in emission sources are one key area of concern
Text: Truck , car , and industrial emissions have all changed over time because of the ongoing efforts to reduce air pollution
Text: These changes have been documented to different degrees , but generally the data include only relatively coarse assessments of total particulate matter and toxic gases
Text: The source-receptor model implies that changes in sources will be reflected in changes in exposure at the receptor
Text: Reductions in total emissions must be assumed to reduce component emissions , which may only be approximately true but difficult to verify .
Text: Estimation of Measurement Error
Text: Quantifying the Exposure of Heavy-Equipment Operators to Respirable Crystalline Silica Dust
Text: ABSTRACT
Text: Respirable-dust sampling was performed for two months during the excavation of a large disposal pit at the Los Alamos National Laboratory Solid Low-Level Radioactive Waste Disposal Facility
Text: The facility is located on a mesa formed through erosion of volcanic ash deposition
Text: Three regulated silica polymorphs are naturally present in the soil in combined concentrations as high as 65 percent
Text: During the excavation , approximately 64,000 cubic meters of earth was removed by heavy equipment , including scrapers , graders , backhoes , and dozers
Text: Samples were collected with a modified NIOSH 7500 method , in which aluminum cyclones following the British Medical Research Council curve were substituted for nylon cyclones
Text: Over 350 samples were collected to assess personal exposure
Text: Gravimetric analysis of the filters was performed on site
Text: The calculated permissible exposure limit ( CPEL ) for dusts containing silica was established at 0.182 milligrams per cubic meter ( mg/m3 ) in accordance with the Code of Federal Regulations ( 29 CFR 1910.1000 , Table 23 )
Text: Respiratory protection was required for all equipment operators until a minimum of 15 samples had been collected for operators of each type of equipment , the samples had been evaluated to assess personal exposure , and the evaluation had confirmed that operator exposure was below the OSHA-calculated permissible exposure limits
Text: Sample analysis revealed respirable-dust concentrations that ranged from 0.014 to 3.169 mg/m3
Text: For various types of equipment , operators received average gross personal exposures as follows : 0.694 mg/m3 for dozers
Text: 0.070 mg/m3 for a pressurized-cab scraper
Text: 0.321 mg/m3 for an enclosed , nonpressurized cab scraper
Text: and 0.257 mg/m3 for graders , Dust control measures included use of an 8,000-gallon water wagon to apply water to the site while work was being performed
Text: This article also discusses variations in dust concentrations and additional control measures .
Text: METHODS AND MATERIALS
Text: To collect all respirable-dust samples , a modified National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health ( NIOSH ) 7500 method was used
Text: Aluminum cyclones from SKC , Inc. , designed to adhere to the British Medical Research Council ( BMRC ) curve , were substituted for the NIOSH-specified cyclone
Text: The substitution was made for three reasons :
Text: 1
Text: a higher flow rate ,
Text: 2
Text: less likelihood of static charge interference , and
Text: 3
Text: a sharper collection efficiency curve around the sampling cut point .
Text: In addition , the aluminum cyclone proved easier to clean and very durable under the rugged field conditions experienced .
Text: Both personal and equipment samples were collected to determine airborne concentrations of respirable dust during earth-disturbing activities
Text: Personal samples were collected with accepted sampling protocol
Text: Equipment samples were collected with the cyclones and sampling pump attached outside the cab at approximately the same height as the operator 's breathing zone
Text: Pump vibration was reduced in equipment samples with a G-inch-thick felt pad placed between the pump and the cab .
Text: Gravimetric analysis of the 37 millimeter ( mm ) diameter , 5.0 micrometer ( µm ) pore size polyvinyl chloride ( PVC ) filters was performed on site
Text: Each filter was exposed to an alpha-emitting source prior to being weighed to eliminate static-charge interference
Text: A microbalance capable of 1 microgram ( µg ) resolution was used for gravimetric analysis of all filter media
Text: The accuracy of the microbalance was verified daily with a series of five reference weights certified to national standards
Text: Throughout the excavation project , balance accuracy was maintained within 3 µg of the reference weights .
Text: RESULTS
Text: Over 350 acceptable respirable-dust samples were collected during excavation of the disposal pit : 175 personal samples and 151 equipment samples
Text: Quality assurance was maintained by the collection and analysis of 38 total-dust laboratory samples and 52 field blanks
Text: Gross concentrations calculated from 175 personal respirable-dust samples collected from the operators of eight types of heavy equipment are shown in Table 1
Text: The comparative statistics given are arithmetic mean ( µ ) and standard deviation ( s )
Text: Gross concentration is defined as the net respirable-dust loading divided by the volume of air sampled for the sample duration only
Text: No adjustment is made to a time-weighted average value
Text: Operators in pressurized cabs received the lowest mean respirable-dust exposure , 0.072 mg/m3
Text: Operators in enclosed , nonpressurized cabs received mean respirable-dust exposures ranging from 0.234 to 0.323 mg/m3 , and operators in open cabs received the highest mean exposures , ranging from 0.426 to 0.837 mg/m3 .
Text: The maximum values presented in Table 1 are clearly above the established CPEL of 0.182 mg/m3 for the eight-hour workday
Text: These values appear to indicate that operators of heavy equipment were overexposed to crystalline silica
Text: Three factors , however , refute that indication
Text: First , all heavy equipment operators were required to wear half-faced respirators until sufficient exposure data confirmed that their exposures were acceptable
Text: Second , the data presented in Table 1 are gross exposures , not time-weighted averages
Text: Finally , the data are purely gravimetric
Text: Each personal sample collected with a filter loading of 100 µg or more was submitted for XRD analysis
Text: The XRD results mandated respiratory protection , thereby ensuring that no personnel were overexposed to respirable crystalline silica during the construction of Pit 38 .
Text: Dozer operators consistently received the highest exposures
Text: For all heavy equipment operators , respirable-dust exposures were matched with pit depth
Text: This process indicated a trend of increased dust concentrations at greater pit depths
Text: however , the Pearson product-moment correlation between pit depth and exposures was calculated to be 0.352
Text: The large standard deviations of the respirable-dust concentrations indicate exposure variability based on operator , task , and environmental conditions .
Text: Table 2 shows gross concentrations calculated on the basis of 151 respirable-dust samples taken from samplers placed on heavy-equipment cabs
Text: Dozer activities generated the highest mean concentrations
Text: they ranged from 0.628 to 0.971 mg/m3 , with standard deviations ranging from 0.212 to 0.352 mg/m3
Text: As with personal samples , standard deviations were very high compared with the means
Text: The relatively low mean dust concentrations generated by backhoe and grader activities were attributed to the lower intensities of their respective activities .
Text: On the second visit to Dalston the continuous smoke filter was fitted with paper impregnated with thymol blue and was run through periods 1 to 4 only
Text: A similar smoke trace was obtained , and the most intense \" bursts \" during the run-in in the evening showed a pink coloration around the smoke
Text: This indicated the presence of small quantities of acid , probably sulphuric acid
Text: The effect was no greater than that observed at times in ordinary urban air .
Text: The concentrations of nitrogen dioxide found in Merton and Dalston garages are shown in Table 9
Text: Some samples were taken continuously throughout each period and others were collected instantaneously in evacuated litre bottles
Text: Analyses from the first Merton experiment show that the nitrogen dioxide appears to follow the concentration of smoke
Text: The results quoted from the second visit to Merton are not necessarily representative of the average concentrations during each period , since they are based on instantaneous samples only
Text: Continuous samples Dalston 0-1 0-03 * 0-2 were taken during each of the two visits to Dalston and these followed the concentration of smoke in a similar manner
Text: The maximum concentration of nitrogen dioxide found outside Dalston garage was 0-02 p.p.m
Text: Samples taken in evacuated bottles a few feet from the end of the exhaust pipes of several buses at each garage contained up to 15 p.p.m
Text: nitrogen dioxide .
Text: Table 10 shows the concentrations of aldehydes found in Merton and Dalston garages
Text: any ketones present would be included in these figures
Text: Results obtained during the three periods when buses were moving in the garage were considerably higher than those obtained during period 3
Text: Two samples taken in evacuated bottles directly from the exhausts of buses at Merton garage were found to contain 20 and 50 p.p.m
Text: of carbon monoxide
Text: The amount of carbon monoxide in the blood of one subject ( BTC ) rose from 0-038 to 0-075 volumes % between 5.30 p.m
Text: and 12.30 a.m. , whilst that in the blood of another subject ( REW ) fell from 0-350 to 0-075 volumes % during the same period
Text: Neither subject was a smoker .
Text: Exposure measurement error will likely affect our assessment of the true relative risk of lung cancer attributable to diesel exhaust exposure
Text: Errors depend on the quality and detail of the data on the sampling sites and historical operations
Text: This error is most likely to be nondifferential ( ie , unrelated to disease status )
Text: Thus , our observed relative risks for a dichotomous exposure will be underestimates of the true relative risk ( Rothman 1981 )
Text: However , the effect of error on the assessment of dose response may go in either direction ( Dosemeci et al 1990
Text: Birkett 1992 ) .
Text: The magnitude of these effects on the observed point estimate of the relative risks can be estimated
Text: A correction factor , γ , can be derived from the variability of EC levels between jobs , between workers in the same job , and within an individual working at the same job over time ( Rosner 2000 )
Text: The true logistic regression coefficient , β* , would then be estimated as the observed β divided by γ , and the confidence intervals of the corrected relative risk would be wider than those of the observed risk .
Text: The data from this feasibility study were too limited to allow direct estimation of measurement error between jobs , urban and rural locations , and large and small terminals
Text: However , we used the GSD between all jobs mea- sured during this feasibility study and estimates of theGSD between and within workers obtained from published data and NIOSH Health Hazard Evaluation Reports to illustrate a few possible examples if lung cancer risk were compared between 2 jobs ( Table 12 )
Text: In our extreme example , if we assume a GSD of 1.4 between jobs , and a combined GSD of 2 between and within workers , the β would be underestimated by 5-fold
Text: The preliminary expo- sure data showed a range of 6 to 7 fold in exposures between large urban truck terminals and small rural terminals
Text: That broad range will allow some imprecision in the numerical estimates of exposure and maintain the ability to detect differences in risk associated with exposure if the GSDs used in these categories are similar to those obtained for job- exposure categories in a larger study
Text: A full study would include more extensive assessment of measurement error .
Text: Samples 1–6 in Table IV were obtained while using a dust collection system sold by SawTec named the Micro mini-vac
Text: The system weighs approximately 46 pounds , is 14 \" W x 52 \" L x 16-1/2 \" H and produces 760 CFM air flow at 8.5 \" maximum static pressure according to SawTec
Text: The vacuum has one 4 \" inlet for a flexible tube
Text: The system uses a bag to collect the suctioned dust
Text: Information with the equipment states that the bag “filters concrete dust to 0.5 micron” ( see Figure 6 )
Text: A metal shroud was attached to the grinder , and a flexible tube connected the vacuum to the shroud
Text: Neither respirable quartz nor respirable dust were detected by the 127-minute personal breathing zone sample
Text: Due to tool and/or system problems the estimated grinding time was 77 minutes
Text: The high-volume area sample ( 9.0 L/min. ) indicated a respirable dust sample concentration of 0.66 mg/m 3 and a respirable quartz sample concentration of 0.04 mg/m 3
Text: The four side-by-side area samples ( 1.7 L/min. ) did not detect respirable quartz , but averaged 0.54 mg/m 3 of respirable dust
Text: The data indicate that short-term sampling may not collect enough dust to permit a quartz measurement
Text: Occasional dust leaks at connections of the air handling system were observed .
Text: Samples 7–12 in Table IV were obtained while using a dust collection system sold by SawTec named the Maxi-vac
Text: According to information available , the system weighs 140 pounds , is 21 \" W x 36 \" L x 78 \" H and produces 900 CFM air flow at 8.5 \" maximum static pressure
Text: The vacuum can be arranged for up to two 4 \" inlets or one 6 \" inlet
Text: The Maxi-vac uses the same bag material as the Micro mini-vac
Text: The Maxi-vac was connected to a shroud on the grinder in a similar fashion as with the Micro mini-vac
Text: The shroud used for this system had a cut-out to allow the disc to reach into corners
Text: The personal breathing zone sample indicated a respirable dust concentration of 1.4 mg/m 3 and a respirable quartz dust concentration of 0.13 mg/m 3 for the 150-minute sample
Text: Due to worker breaks and interruptions the estimated actual grinding time was 96 minutes
Text: This quartz concentration , if maintained for an 8- to 10-hour shift , would be over 2-1/2 times the NIOSH REL
Text: Even if no exposure is assumed for the remainder of the shift , the 8-hour TWA would be 0.04 mg/m 3
Text: The high-volume area sample ( 9.0 L/min. ) indicated a respirable dust concentration of 0.61 mg/m 3 and a respirable quartz concentration of 0.03 mg/m 3 during the 150-minute sample
Text: The four side-by-side area samples did not detect respirable quartz , but found an average of 0.53 mg/m 3 of respirable dust
Text: Occasional dust leaks at connections of the air handling system were observed .
Text: Samples 13–18 in Table IV were obtained while using a WAP dust collection system , which is a type of canister vacuum
Text: The WAP vacuum has a 10-gallon capacity and uses 1600 watts with 13 amps or 1000 watts with 8.3 amps
Text: The system uses disposable paper filter bags
Text: A flexible tube was used to connect it to a shroud fitted to the grinder
Text: The 117-minute personal breathing zone sample resulted in a respirable dust concentration of 0.30 mg/m 3
Text: Respirable quartz was not detected
Text: Due to worker breaks and interruptions the estimated actual grinding time was 100 minutes
Text: The high-volume area sample ( 9.0 L/min. ) indicated a respirable dust concentration of 0.26 mg/m 3 and a respirable quartz concentration between the limits of detection and quantification of 0.02 mg/m 3
Text: None of the four side-by-side area samples detected respirable dust .
Text: Concrete Sawing
Text: Table V summarizes the concrete sawing data
Text: Samples 1–4 were obtained at an office building remodeling project
Text: A worker used a gasoline-powered handheld masonry saw ( see Figure 7 ) to saw indentations in the concrete floor on each of the 16 floors of the building so that restroom floor drains could be installed
Text: The concrete cutting was done by a plumber
Text: The saw was used without water being applied to the blade or using a dust collector
Text: The only attempt to control the dust was with the use of a floor stand fan directed toward an open window
Text: The investigators found a respirable concentration of quartz for the concrete cutter operator of 14.0 mg/m 3 during a 350-minute sample
Text: The area samples for this operation were found to be 4.1 , 3.4 , and 3.2 mg/m 3 respirable quartz
Text: Three bulk samples of the concrete dust were found to be 38 , 47 , and 43 percent silica .
Text: Samples 5–12 were taken during highway construction
Text: This site consisted of a four-lane highway being constructed , during which expansion joints were being sawed in the fresh concrete within six hours of being placed
Text: Three workers were involved in the operation
Text: Two of the workers operated commercial-type walk-behind concrete saws and the third operated a water truck , which provided water to the saws
Text: Hoses transported water from the water truck to the saws so that the diamond-tipped saw blades could be cooled while in use
Text: Neither the saw operators nor the water truck driver used respiratory protection
Text: The water truck driver spent almost all of his time in the cab of the water truck while the saws were in use .
Text: Samples 13–15 were obtained during reconstruction of an interstate highway bridge where blocks of the old concrete were sawed completely through so the old pavement could be removed
Text: This operation consisted of three workers operating concrete saws to saw through the decking of an existing bridge
Text: Each of the saws was equipped with a water supply that provided water to the diamond-impregnated saw blades
Text: Water was obtained from tanks mounted on the back of trucks , and was transported by gasoline pumps to the saws
Text: General area air samples were collected to determine the potential exposure concentrations of respirable silica dust
Text: The duration of the air sampling was approximately three hours , due to inclement weather .
Text: Samples 16–24 were obtained during repair of an interstate highway
Text: Blocks of the old concrete pavement that needed to be replaced were sawed through and lifted out so that new concrete could be poured ( see Figure 8 )
Text: This operation consisted of two workers operating two concrete saws to saw blocks of concrete pavement
Text: Each of the saws was equipped with a water supply that provided water to the diamond-tipped saw blades
Text: For each saw , water was obtained from 725-gallon water tanks mounted on trucks
Text: The water source for the two saws was under pressure from 3.5 and 4.0 horsepower water pumps
Text: The workers did not use respirators .
Text: Asphalt/Concrete Milling
Text: Table VI summarizes data obtained during two shifts of asphalt milling
Text: This operation consisted of three workers operating an asphalt mill to remove old asphalt from an interstate highway ( see Figure 9 )
Text: This machine operates similarly to the continuous mining machines used in coal mining with a horizontal drum studded with carbide bits and a water spray system to wet down dust
Text: The mill is set to remove a predetermined depth of asphalt or concrete
Text: For the operation reported here , the entire thickness of asphalt was removed from the underlying concrete pavement , thereby abrading the concrete surface in the process
Text: The operator spent almost all of his time on top of the mill in the open
Text: A laborer spent his time walking alongside the machine , as did the foreman
Text: None of the workers used respirators .
Text: Although respirable dust was found in the breathing zone of the mill operator during both shifts , quartz was not detected
Text: On both days , elevated levels of respirable quartz were found in the breathing zone of the laborer
Text: During the first shift ( samples 1–6 ) , the 8-hour TWA for respirable quartz dust was 0.36 mg/m 3
Text: This concentration is over 7 times the NIOSH REL of 0.05 mg/m 3
Text: During the second shift ( samples 7 – 11 ) , the 8-hour TWA for respirable quartz dust was 0.10 mg/m 3 , or twice the NIOSH REL
Text: During the first shift , the investigators found 8-hour TWA respirable quartz concentrations ranging from the REL to over 4 times the REL at Area 1 above the conveyor belt
Text: During the second shift , quartz was detected in the Area 1 samples , although at levels too low to quantify
Text: The Area 2 sample during the first shift ( sample 6 ) located on the top of machine ( front end ) also detected quartz at a level too low to quantify .
Text: The results show that the laborer walking beside the machine was being exposed to respirable quartz at levels above the NIOSH REL and the OSHA PEL
Text: The mill was provided with water from a water truck
Text: During these types of operations maintenance of the water spray system is essential to assure that it is working as intended
Text: Possible problems may include spray nozzle misalignment or water not being provided at high enough pressure
Text: Dust may leak out the sides of the machine , and therefore may require additional water sprays
Text: An additional water spray may be needed at the conveyor belt
Text: Care should be taken to insure that water is always provided to the drum while in operation
Text: The mill should be shut down if it runs out of water before the water truck can return with a new load .
Text: In 1999 , employers were contributing to the Western Conference Pension Trust for 270,744 employees , with 14,228 members ( 5.3 % ) coming from the 4 large unionized carriers
Text: Overall , 169,667 Teamster retirees were receiving benefits from the Western Conference Pension Trust , but the proportion of retirees from the 4 large unionized carriers was not obtained for this report
Text: Therefore , of the 72,666 active Teamsters union members in the 4 companies in 1999 , 49.6 % belonged to Central States Pension Fund and 19.6 % belonged to Western Conference PensionTrust , for a total of 69.2 % of the workers currently contributing to one of the two large Teamsters union retirement plans
Text: Approximately 25 small funds accounted for the other 30.9 % of the workers’ retirement benefits .
Text: The 2 pension funds we studied maintain computerized records of the contributions made by each unionized trucking company on behalf of a worker , including dates and company name
Text: In the Central States Pension Fund , the only specific job histories available are the self-reports provided by each worker when he or she completes an application at the time of retirement
Text: The applicant lists job title and dates of service with each employer
Text: this information is not verified against company records
Text: In the Central StatesP ension Fund , starting in 1992 , these records are available from an image retrieval system , and prior to 1992 , on microfiche
Text: No job history information is collected by theWestern Conference Pension Trust
Text: No other specific details about job title and location are maintained by either fund , and medical information and information on personal habits , such as cigarette smoking , are not collected .
Text: Thus , although the pension funds can not provide many details about a participant’s job history or risk factors , they can provide information on total years of creditable service as a Teamster , beyond what is available from the current or last employer , and they provide an independent means of verifying data on work in the unionized trucking industry .
Text: COMPANY RECORDS ON TRUCK FLEETS
Text: Vehicle and Equipment Records
Text: Each company has 2 computerized systems containing vehicle and equipment information : asset registers and maintenance records
Text: The extent and availability of these records vary by company
Text: Asset registers record the following information about every truck and forklift purchased or sold by the company : vehicle serial number , make , model , year , and engine type as well as location assignment for forklifts and P & D vehicles
Text: The asset registers are computerized and available for all vehicles ever owned by one of the companies , from the 1980s for 2 companies , and for the last 5 years from the other
Text: Additional information may be retrievable from paper records starting as early as 1959 in one company
Text: Furthermore , long-time personnel in the asset and maintenance departments often are able to reconstruct much of this information from memory , because companies typically purchased only one or two types of trucks per year
Text: The maintenance departments keep information on vehicle component changes , such as engine overhauls and air-conditioning removals
Text: These data supplement those provided by the asset registers , and although some are computerized for some companies , they are available mainly in paper form .
Text: An historical listing of the number and design of diesel P & D vehicles assigned to each terminal and the composition of the long-haul fleet can be constructed for each company
Text: Long-haul vehicles are not assigned to a terminal and are used throughout a company’s system
Text: However , the long-haul drivers are assigned to a specific home terminal , which indicates the region where they drive .
Text: From the preliminary information provided , we constructed a timeline for the conversion to diesel long-haul vehicles , P & D trucks , and forklifts ( Table 5 )
Text: Each company started using long-haul diesel trucks in the 1950s , and all 4 companies had converted from gasoline long-haul vehicles by 1965
Text: Diesel vehicles were introduced into the P & D fleets beginning in 1972
Text: Depending on the company , the year that the P & D fleet was 100 % diesel varied considerably ( 1980 to 1992 ) , but the majority of combined fleets were diesel by the late 1980s
Text: Diesel forklifts were in general use by the mid 1980s
Text: They were then phased out between 1990 and 1996 and were replaced with propane units as part of contract negotiation with the Teamsters union in the early 1990s
Text: According to information from one company , diesel forklifts were most likely to be used in the large distribution centers but not in the smaller local terminals
Text: Company records can be used to identify where diesel forklifts were used .
Text: Historical Changes in Vehicle Use
Text: Vehicle replacement and utilization practices differ among the 4 companies
Text: Three of the 4 companies have historically converted long-haul vehicles to P & D vehicles after 10 to 15 years of service and then used them for an additional 10 to 15 years
Text: Each company keeps its vehicles in service for different lengths of time , and within each company this policy has changed historically
Text: The trend is toward keeping the vehicles on the road longer
Text: Because of these policies , the age of the fleets varies substantially between companies
Text: For example , data from one company showed that several hundred trucks purchased in 1975 to 1979 are still in service , whereas another company keeps its vehicles for only 5 years .
Text: Maintenance policies for all 4 companies generally call for restoring vehicles to original operating conditions rather than replacing the engines ( although different engines may be installed in some of the older vehicles )
Text: Any replacement of engines is recorded and archived
Text: The long-haul vehicles have been air conditioned for many years ( for example , new vehicles purchased by one company have been air conditioned since approximately 1980 )
Text: Since P & D vehicles are not air conditioned , the air conditioning is removed when a long-haul vehicle is converted to local use .
Text: TERMINAL CHARACTERISTICS
Text: Through analysis of annual reports , personnel records , terminal operation records , and other company sources ( such as maps and company histories ) , the total number of terminals and the size of each terminal at each of the 4 companies starting in 1985 were determined
Text: Current terminal addresses were obtained from all companies and historical terminal addresses from one company
Text: Samples of terminal blueprints illustrating design features were obtained from some of the companies
Text: We have determined that it is feasible to obtain this information on all relevant terminals .
Text: Terminal codes and the number of employees assigned to each terminal are available from the personnel databases
Text: In 1985 there were 2,200 work locations in the personnel data- bases
Text: the number increased to 2,427 by 1990
Text: Since 1990 , the trend has been toward a reduction in the number of smaller terminals , and the total number of work locations decreased to 1,770 in 1995 and 1,337 in 1999
Text: However , because some of the work locations specified in the personnel files are at the same physical address or terminal ( in other words , office areas and repair shops may have unique codes ) , the number of total terminals is overestimated
Text: For example , there were only 1,267 unique terminals in the address files in 1999
Text: Therefore , historical address information ( available from all companies ) should be used to determine unique terminal addresses in a larger study
Text: Of the 1,267 unique addresses in 1999 , most were terminals with fewer than 30 employees ( Table 6 )
Text: Because background air pollution ( and respirable particle levels ) vary with urban or rural location , the addresses of the 1999 terminals were overlaid on a map of the United States ( Figure 2 ) and classified as urban or rural as defined by the US Census Bureau
